text:
Hi, everyone!  Gosh, I haven't checked these reviews for years.  I'm so glad to see there are so many people loving this recipe.  HEY... be sure to enter this chili in contests at work... it WINS all the time :-)  Last Friday I just won 1st place for "Hot"' category, and overall grand champion for receiving the most points from the judges.
Now... I have a couple of BIG secrets to share with you about this recipe, that might make it EVEN BETTER.  When I entered it online in 2000, the use of brand names weren't allowed, so I'll try to enter them here so you know.  The salsa is actually PACE PICANTE SAUCE... Med. or Hot.  The chili seasoning I use is Williams Original (not available in all areas), I use one package per 2 lbs of ground beef... sometimes I throw in a little extra from another package.

Enjoy! Best regards, Deb.

text:
I wish I could give more than 5 stars to this recipe!

The chili I've been making for years is my mom's recipe, and it's really more like a thick spaghetti sauce than a chunky chili. I needed a new recipe for a chili sale at my work, and it needed to taste great.

Deb's recipe did not disappoint. I used Pace salsa (I think it's called Chipolte???) with jalapenos for a little extra kick and added a can of Rotel tomatoes and green chilis.

Everyone who tried it raved over the great flavor, and a lot of folks asked for the recipe. It had a little bit of a spicy aftertaste, but was mild enough to appeal to all but the pickiest eaters. My husband even asked me to make a batch for him to take to work Superbowl Sunday. I will never go searching for another chili recipe again! Thanks Deb!!!!!

text:
HELPFUL TIPS: I halved the recipe because it's just for my husband and 2 toddlers (although one eats like a monster!), and we still had leftovers :)  Put the normal amount of onion and black pepper.  One 10oz. of diced tomatoes w/green chiles and one 14oz of tomato sauce because it needed it.  HALF a jar of chunky salsa (although I will do a taste test an hour in to see if I need more), half a jar of each DRAINED kidney bean, and half a can of ranch style chili beans (pinto beans).  They are the best beans on earth.  Added one can of drained mushrooms and 3/4 a can of drained corn.  After I browned 1 lb of meat, I put it in the crock pot for at least 2.5hrs.  Grrrreat!  We have it at least once every few months for the past several years!  Update: I now add things like diced green, yellow and red peppers which really adds to the taste (and gives it color).  Season with a few dashes of garlic, oregano, paprika, basil, sugar, and we're talking a real winner!  Our family eats it with rice the first night (fri), sat is "let's be lazy day," so we eat it over hot dogs, and sun ...can you say football and fritos and chili over cheese!!  We're not obsessed w/this recipe ...really ;)

text:
Wow Deb and thanks for the easiest dang chili recipe I ever made - and with all the ingredients already in the house!  I used 1 lb. ground chuck and 1 lb. ground turkey and added 1 can of pinto beans to the mix. Made a mistake and used the whole pack of the chili seasoning mix, but it came out tasting great.  I recommend using either fresh garlic or garlic powder because the taste to me is the best.  The nicest thing was that you could spice the recipe up or down depending on the type of salsa you used.  I just browned the meat and onions, and threw everything into the crockpot and forgot about it for 8 hours on low.
Came home to yummy smells from the kitchen. Next time I will add green and read bell pepper.

Chili cheese fries?  You all are killing me!  LOL
--------------------------------------------------------
I originally wrote this review over 7 years ago, and It is still my go to chili recipe because it is so adaptable.  Chili season is approaching and I can't wait to make it again.  I wish I could give this 10 stars as it is that good........  BTW, I did have to indulge in those chili cheese fries and they were heavenly - as were the chili dogs and chiliburgers, and mexican omletes.  LOL
Debzdoo, you are my chili queen!

text:
This chili is wonderful! I was looking for a recipe for chili that would be as good as Wendy's chili, this chili doesn't taste exactly the same, but it is just as good. It is very easy to make, takes very little time to prepare, and it's so super delicious! I did tweak the recipe a bit, I used crushed tomatoes instead of tomato sauce, and I used more than the recipe called for. I also increased the meat a little and threw in a can of pinto beans in addition to the light and dark kidney beans, and I added a little cayenne pepper to spice it up a little more.

We love this recipe.  We make this all the time and we even made a big pot of it for our Super Bowl party.  We always use a couple cloves of garlic instead of garlic salt because we don't have any at home.  We use between 2-3 tsps of the chili seasoning and serve it with an assortment of toppings: dollop of sour cream, shredded cheese, green onions.  Thank you so much for an easy chili recipe.

text:
Have made this recipe a couple of times and thought it not only easy but very tasty. And, as with any chili recipe, it lends itself to experimentation - or just adjusting to what you know your family will like.  What I really have a hard time with is when someone rates a recipe without EVER having tried it - and giving it only one star to boot.  If you look at a recipe and know that it has features that you don't like - then go on to the next one.  It is completely unfair to give a really poor rating to something that you KNOW you aren't going to like and even more importantly have not even tried.  That's mean spirited.

text:
My husband who loves chili, really loved this and was amazed that it was so easy to make. You can really alter this as much as you like. I used tomato sauce made for chili, 16 oz mild salsa, Chili-o seasoning (the whole packet), and Busch's chili beans (1 large in mild and 1 med in medium sauce). I also, added Borden's shredded cheese with taco seasoning. I omitted the garlic salt and used fresh garlic and a whole onion. My hubby said he would like some corn in it next time. It was a hit.  As a note I'd like to add that for such a quick and easy recipe, it shouldn't harshly be compared to more extensive recipes. It's a great quick and tasty recipe worthy of 5 stars.

Very good and very easy. I did as another reviewer suggested and substituted a 15 oz. can of tomatoes and a 15 oz. can of tomato sauce for the 2 1/2 cups of tomato sauce. text:
I only gave 4 stars because I made some changes. Instead of a packet of taco seasoning I used "Taco seasoning I" found on this website and added it as soon as the meat was cooked. While the meat was defrosting I started the onions in a separate pan and caramelized them (adds a kick of sweet to the chili) and added them in once the meat was browner a seasoned. I also half everything (as much as possible) in the recipe. It's a GREAT base recipe and allows for a lot of personal modifications. Oh and since I halved it I just used one can of light red beans and not both kinds

text:
During a particularly cold spell, I decided I wanted chili; however, I didn't want to use my standard recipe that has a LONG list of ingredients. I looked on Allrecipes and found this simple recipe. Boy, am I glad I gave it a try!!  It was yummy!  I used an entire packet of McCormick's chili seasoning mix and also added about 1C chopped green pepper to it (personal preference).  Then topped it with sour cream and cheddar cheese.  My son and I gobbled it up!  Thanks for such an easy, and OUTSTANDING, chili recipe!  My new favorite, for sure!

text:
put three cups of this chili on top of half of a batch of  prepared cornbread batter (I use Jiffy), add 1 and half cups of shredded cheese, then pour on the rest of the batter and cook according to cornbread cooking directions, add 1/2 cup of the cheese as soon as you take it out of the oven and let it melt. My family loves this, we call it Cowboy Cornbread! Very yummy and filling!

text:
This chili is a pretty good, simple chili.  I like that it can be thrown together pretty quickly, and that it is versatile.  Sometimes I will put in a can or two of stewed tomatoes instead of salsa, or I will use black beans or whatever kind I have on hand.  We like to use this recipe to make "frito burritos".  We will make the chili as directed and then put it in a flour tortilla with some cheese and fritos. 

Not the best chili I ever had, but definitely decent for the amount of time it takes to prepare.

I was skeptical how a chili recipe this easy could be so good, but it certainly is! 
I have other recipes that result in a good chili, but this one is just as good if not better, and SO much quicker & easier! I made mine using the "hot" Pace picante sauce, and used fresh garlic. I let mine simmer in the slow cooker all day and what a treat it was! 
Otherwise, I followed the recipe exactly, after reading Deb's helpful tips in her review, and it was amazingly fabulous chili.....thanks for sharing Deb! This will definitely be my "go-to recipe" for chili from now on!

Well...this was the first time that I had made meat chili. Hard to believe, but true. My family really enjoyed this recipe. It got rave reviews for sure. My fussy daughter, who never likes anything btw, just jobbled down 2 bowls! Instead of adding the 2.5 c tomato sauce, I subbed 15 oz diced tomatoes and 15 oz. tom. sauce. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this chili out of curiosity because the reviews were so great. However, I usually "throw my chili together" close to the same way each time I make it, and it's very good....my family, my husband and in-laws LOVE my chili.  Also, I made a few small changes to this recipe: I used lean ground turkey in place of ground beef; I knew I'd be adding 1 more can of beans so used a full 16 oz jar of Newmans' Own Salsa instead of an 8 oz jar; 1 large onion instead of 1/2 of an onion; 1/2 tsp garlic powder in place of garlic salt; added 1/4 tsp salt; 1 can each black, pinto, and white beans instead of 2 cans kidney beans.  I also added 1/2 tsp liquid smoke. As I said, it was pretty good, and a nice change of pace. However I will probably return to my old standard. If I get enough interest, I'll post my recipe.

city:

country:

text:
I love the ease and simpleness of this recipe! It's just good chili that is quick to make. If you want leftovers, then be sure to double this recipe. I followed the recipe exactly as it is the first time I made it, and it was excellent. Other times that I've made it and doubled the recipe, I add about 2 teaspoons of white sugar as well as a green pepper, which I cook with the meat and onions.  I drain the fat out of the meat and I don't strain the beans. I used the Chili Seasoning Mix II recipe from this site, and the chili was awesome! I will say that the first time I made this, it was pretty spicy for me, but that might have something to do with the chili seasoning, and not really this recipe. When I eat other chili that friends or relatives make, I always wish that I was eating this chili instead (but of course I'll never tell them that)!

text:
I made this last night for the Superbowl, and it was the most amazing bowl of chili I have ever had in my life! I made a half batch of this with 1lb of beef (it was all I had in the freezer) and used the Chili seasoning mix II from this site (amazing!). I used 1 can of vegetarian baked beans instead of kidney beans, because I like the texture of them better, and added about 1/2 a bottle of dark-ish beer. This chili has a great kick to it, I didn't even have to add Cayenne. Once it was cooked just topped it with a little extra sharp cheddar and I was in game-day heaven. Thank you sooo much for posting, this is definately going to be a weekly dish for me and hubby!

text:
Really great recipe!  I had never made chili before, but I decided to enter my hometown's chili cookoff with this recipe.  I doubled the recipe, added an extra can of tomato sauce, and threw in some chili garlic sauce, a tablespoon or so of Bullfighter steak sauce, and substituted one can of the light red kidney beans with black beans.  Also, when I sauteed the ground beef and onion I sauteed them with about 5 cloves of fresh pressed garlic instead of using the garlic salt.  VERY EASY TO MAKE!  And, the best part is that I won second place in the cookoff - pretty good for never having made chili before!

text:
I have to give this recipe kudos for being quick and easy.  I decided at the last minute that I wanted to make chili and was able to throw this together quickly without a trip to the grocery.  I am sure that the chili seasoning makes a huge difference in flavor and perhaps what I had in my pantry was not a good choice.  I used fresh garlic because everything is better with fresh garlic and one can kidney and one can chili beans because that is what I had on hand.   I was surprised that a chili with so few ingredients could win awards and garner so many five star reviews but was hopeful.  Even after an overnight in the fridge, however, this chili was just okay for us.

country:
None
text:
Best chili ever!
I made my own salsa because i didn't have any store bought salsa in my pantry. I also made my own chili mix from this website. It takes a little bit longer but it was well worth it.
Tomato salsa recipe- 1 canned  tomatos diced, 1/2 onion diced, 1/3c green bell pepper diced, 1 jalapeno, seeded and minced, 2 cloves garlic minced, 1/4 fresh cilantro chopped, salt to taste. Mix all ingredients in a bowl.  Cover and refrigerate at least 1 hour before serving.

userID:
2638282
Display Name:
Micah Funk
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2158854.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is such a quick recipe to make that generally can be made without making a trip to the grocery store.  This recipe has such a very well balanced delicious taste, EVEN when it is only cooked for an hour or less!

I've tried several other chili recipes and this one is the favorite of my family. It isn't a thin or runny chili but it is thick and hearty. The flavor isn't to heavy on the tomato side or the meat side; it's just incredible!

We like to double the recipe and eat it for a few meals or freeze some for later. 

We love the recipe as is, but we also have added frozen corn, a can of diced tomatoes with green chilies, and lil' smokies. Using the Pace Southwest Chipotle Restaurant Style Salsa was delicious. Cover the top with shredded cheese and a big dollop of sour cream... my mouth is starting to water just thinking about it!
-- If for your taste it has to much tomato taste, try adding the diced tomatoes with green chilies; this is a quick way to add spices and more of that chili flavor to balance the taste. Also, the salsa can make or break this recipe! Using the PACE SOUTHWEST CHIPOTLE RESTAURANT STYLE SALSA adds a depth of flavor that doesn't have a strong tomato flavor. Chances are, if you don't love this recipe as it is, you need to use these specific ingredients I've spoken about to keep the correct flavor balance. -- GOOD EATING

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/914561.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe lives up to the hype.  Like most Allrecipe chefs, I made a few changes that I had to make based on principle.  I used 5 cloves of garlic instead of the garlic salt.  I seasoned the ground beef with a great deal more pepper than the recipe calls for (nearly 2 teaspoons).  And I added about two teaspoons of chili powder in addition to the package of McCormick's Chili packet.  I used two jars of Pace HOT Salsa instead of one (for a total of 16 ounces).  And I added one 14 ounce can of diced tomatos.  Even with the added moisture, it is still maintained its hardy consistency.  As for the onion, I did not cook it with the ground beef but served it diced raw on top of each serving.  This makes a great deal of chili.  With my changes, it is definately a 5 alarm chili (for children and for those with delicate palates, use the mild version of the salsa and skip the extra chili powder).  Thank you, Deb.  This is now my go to recipe when the urge strikes.  For those that are wondering what makes this such a good chili, it's the salsa.   For whatever reason, it works very well in this application.
Review:

5

country:

text:
I was very surprised that this was so good, with so few ingredients.  I will admit, this is not a knock your socks off stand out chili, but it is really good for the little amount of work that goes into it.  I used a whole 28oz can of tomato sauce, the whole 24oz bottle of Pace Picante sauce, and an entire packet of McCormicks original chili seasoning.  Usually, making chili takes a lot of time and ingredients for me.  This will become a go to recipe for a basic chili that doesn't take much work and tastes great.  Oh, I also added an extra can of beans, just because a) we like beans and b) we wanted to stretch this meal a little with meat getting so expensive.

I have made this recipe a few times in the last few months and everyone loves it. The best part is its easily customized to different levels of heat. I've already had to give this recipe out multiple times.

Just made this chili last night and was overall great. I modified the recipe slightly using 3 cups of tomato sauce, 1 can of kidney beans, 1 can of chili beans, 1 can of black beans and used the vegetarian "ground smart" in place of the meat. text:
This chili is very good. I modified it as some suggested by adding a can of Rotel with green chilies, more seasonings (i.e., garlic powder, seasoned salt, basil, paprika, oregano), and a can of Bushs chili beans in mild sauce instead of the dark kidney beans, and a little sugar. My 5-year old daughter did not like it maybe because I served it with rice, but in any event, the next time, I will probably use a little bit more spice 'kick' (perhaps use hot Pace picanta salsa instead of the mild sauce). I also made cornbread to eat with this. This recipe yields a lot! I will definitely make this again. Thanks for the submission and modification ideas!

text:
Hooooooweeee! (That's Texas for "HOLY ").  This recipe is amazing, and deserves all the awards it's won. I followed Deb's advice in the first comment and used Pace Picante Sauce (Hot) instead of regular salsa. The heat doesn't hit you at first, but just wait a few seconds and your mouth will be on fire.

For an extra kick, use Buffalo meat instead of hamburger, and maybe a can of pinto beans as well for a heartier chili.

text:
This chili is so good, and so darn easy to make. I made the recipe exactly as written and it got raves. I have to comment on a couple of things that aren't specified or are optional. You need to drain the beans. Maybe that's a given, but it didn't specify, and being a new cook, I wasn't sure. Also, I would highly recommend draining the grease. I have made it both ways and it's much better when made with drained meat. But quite delicious regardless! 5 stars, period!

text:
This was quite good and made a good amount - we used 1 package ground turkey and 1 lb ground beef which seemed to give it a nice texture (or was it the slow cooking?) I used McCormick's chili seasoning packet (nearly 1.5) and made chili mac with it.  After cooking it on the stove, I threw it into a lined slow cooker for 2 hours (I was afraid to scorch the chili in the pot on the stove) and it was awesome.  Added a little extra tomato sauce to finish up the can (which is fine because we needed the sauce for the chili mac).  Good stuff! Great with a spoonful of sour cream.

text:
Deb says that this recipe wins in every chili cook-off she enters it. So I entered this recipe in our church's annual chili cook-off. I have never been a great cook, so I thought it probably won't win any prizes. I live in Texas so the competition is fierce, and I had to enter it in the "Non-Texas" category because it has beans in it. (However, that's where the majority of entries were!) The judging was done blindly; the judges tasted in a separate room and the chilis were numbered. Mine was lucky no. 7 (out of 14 in the category), and it won! It is a true blue-ribbon recipe. It got lots of compliments. It could have been a might spicier for my Texan taste, but for those not used to spice it's perfect--award-winning in fact!

text:
A thick and superb chili. Simple and easy to make is an added bonus. Per DEBZDOOs review, I substituted Pace Picante Sauce, Hot for the salsa and used a 1.75 oz. packet of Frenchs Chili-O Original Seasoning Mix (almost 5 tablespoons) as I could not find Williams Original. I substituted minced garlic for the garlic salt to lower the hefty 55% daily value of sodium for 1 serving  other ingredients add a sufficient amount of salt. This chili recipe is among the top rated and most saved, and that nearly says it all. Well be making this over and over again, and many thanks to Deb for sharing her prize winning recipe.

country:
None
text:
Made this last night for supper and everyone loved it, including the picky one. Pickiest of them all was asking if there was any left over she could have for supper tonight and wanted me to make it again since there wasn't. It is a very good Chili though doesn't make a very big pot. The key to a good Chili soup is to simmer and then let set for a couple hours before eating. I used a quart of my own home canned tomato juice instead of of the tomato sauce and a pint of my own salsa is all I did different. Oh kids like noodles in theirs so I cooked some macaroni on the side for the 2 that wanted that.

text:
This chili was just what I wanted in chili....nothing funky, nothing I never expected to be in chili....just standard, good chili.  It was a little bit spicy for us, but I can never be totally sure how close my version is to the original, because we live in Germany and the ingredients are sometimes a little different, like the chili seasoning.  I added a little more tomato sauce, because it was a little bit thick.  Next time I will add less chili seasoning.  This chili wasn't the best I've ever had, but it was the best I've made and I will make it again.  It's perfect for hotdogs!

Well this is certainly an easy chili.  Like most people I used the chili mix from this site.  Okay so I figured out why it was dry the last time I made it, I used tomato paste instead of sauce. I will certainly make this again, thanks so much for sharing.

text:
One of the simplest chili recipes I have ever made, and simply THE BEST.  For seasoning, I used the recipe Chili Seasoning Mix II (from this site) minus the flour.  Delicious!  One word of advice for those who don't like spicy heat: watch the salsa that you use for this dish.  I am no wimp when it comes to spiciness.  I use a medium salsa, and the end result is always very spicy.

text:
This is a quick recipe that can be easily modified to you own taste.  

I like to season ground beef while it is browning with a little seasoned salt, pepper, garlic powder, onion powder, and worcestshire sauce.  After all the ingredients were combined and had cooked for 30 minutes, I sprinkled all of the same seasonings, plus a 3 dashes of hot sauce, and a couple of pinches of pinches of granulated sugar to break up the acidity. The results were awesome! My whole family loved it!

text:
Wonderfully simple and tasty!  I used home-canned salsa and tomato sauce, which can sometimes taste a bit more acidic than commercial, so I added a little bit of brown sugar to counteract the acidity.  The recipe didn't specify whether or not to drain the bean liquid; to reduce sodium, I did drain them and didn't miss that liquid at all.  I served this with sour cream and grated cheddar cheese on the side - it was delicious with or without the extras!  My hubby has already requested I make this again.

text:
This chili was so easy to make, & delicious.

After the chili had simmered for one hour: I layered the chili onto a bed of  white tortilla chips on a baking sheet, put a layer of mild grated cheddar cheese on it, & baked it in the oven until the cheese melted.

Then served the loaded nachos with 4 different bowls of cold condiments: shredded lettuce, sour cream, guacamole, fresh mild salsa, to dip.

I wish I would have picked up pickled jalepenos & sliced black olives too. Next time!

It was fun to eat the chili this way & we enjoyed the meal.

Thank you for this excellent recipe. I also loved that I didn't need to use a knife at all to prepare this entire meal! Preparation was so simple & efficient.

text:
Now, that's a great bowl of red!! Very easy recipe, no unnecessary flavors/ingredients, and was on the table in about 2 hours start to finish. I followed the recipe as given and we loved the taste but because we enjoy a little "sweat" with our chili I added some cayenne pepper and simmered a bit longer. Personally, we think that only upped the overall appeal.  By far this is a great base chili to get creative with your own familys likes and dislikes. A different salsa, diced tomatoes in place of sauce, some chopped green pepper, more or less beans  the combinations are endless  but so delicious!!  Heres a suggestion that doesnt pertain to this recipe, but chili in general  both of my grandmas and great-grams added diced potatoes to their chili  sometimes sweet corn  who knew?!  Thanks for sharing your recipe!

text:
I almost wish I had a chili contest to enter this into!  Of course being from the SW I modified it just a little. I used one pound of buffalo and one of ground beef.  Instead of tomato sauce I used 2 cans of diced tomatos with fire roasted chiles, half a jar of hot salsa - though I may add the other half jar later.  Then to sneak in more veggies I grated one large carrot and diced up two large ribs of celery.  This is the chili recipe I've been looking for for a long time!

text:
Good basic recipe but not spicy enough for me. Went with 1# ground beef, 1# hot sausage and added another tbs chili pepper, 1.5 tsp of salt, and 1 can beef broth. If you want it hot add 2 tsp diced jalapenos. Like mine a little smoother rather than chunky so I pureed 1/2 mixture for the texture I like. Everyone's different but I think the changes I made put it over the top.

text:
Our new favorite chili recipe!  Easy to prepare with fabulous results.  Could not find William's Original so I had to substitute with Lawry's Chili Seasoning.  Used a potato masher to finely mince the browning meat.  Added the beans and mashed lightly again to open up the beans for a smoother texture. Topped with a little shredded cheddar, sour cream and minced green onion...this is chili perfection!

This was SOOOO good!!!My husband is VERY particular and picky about his chili because his dad makes the "best" chili (in his eyes) that he's ever had. I was unsure how he'd like this considering how simple it seemed; however, he raved about how delicious it was! Display Name:
Katherine Duweck

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4532957.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is GREAT, and ridiculously easy! Slightly on the sweet side, probably because of the onion I used, very pleasing and you can kick up the heat or tone it down from the chili seasoning you use! I let it simmer for about 2 hours, 3 if you have time. Even better the next day! Total keeper for ease and wonderful results!
UPDATE: I have made this....dozens....of times at this point. Ii is still amazing. This recipe is extremely flexible; when I need to make it on the cheap, use 1 lb 80/20 ground beef, double the onion, use a whole 15 oz jar of salsa, (3) 15 oz cans of beans, and a 28oz can of diced tomatoes, and a 15oz can of tomato sauce. If you happen to have fresh garlic cloves, put 2 or 3 of those in there, too. Corn bread is a GREAT side to fill you up on the cheap, too.
I can make a POT of this for $9 or less by cutting the beef and making it veggie heavy. Shop sales to make it even less expensive. Keeps in the fridge for DAYS or freeze it.

text:
I am originally from Texas and I have made my own version of chili for years but when I saw this one, I had to try it. Following the recipe to the "T" (retired military) and using Debdoozie's update using the Pace picante sauce (it is made in my hometown of San Antonio) and McCormicks chili seasoning mix, (my only choice locally) my family absolutely love it over my own rendition. This is a keeper, thanks!

text:
The only change I made was that I used one envelope of chili seasoning mix (1 1/2 tbsp) instead of the 4 tbsp. I prefer a mild chili and one envelope was perfect. Adding more would add way too much sodium (1 envelope has 420mg). I had Mild Salsa on hand, so that is what I used. You could always make this hotter by using Hot Salsa or add chili powder. I will make this again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious!
I've been wanting chili for the past week and I finally decided that I would make it myself. I used this recipe and I also used some of the pointers that I found in the reviews. 
I used ground turkey, red onion, no garlic salt.
I added a can of drained corn, a can of drained mushroom and used the whole can of both of the kidneys (after draining them). I also didn't use as much of the chili seasoning (didn't want it to be too salty).  
I let it simmer for an hour and I served it with corn bread and shredded reduced fat cheese.
Everyone loved it! Will be my staple chili recipe!

text:
I was worried there would be too much spice. But using the full spices and only 3/4 cup of salsa walked the line perfectly between adaquate to give it a kick while being edible.  Unfortunately, it tastes like every other chili out there. With way too much beef - 2 POUNDS!! That's insane. Maybe if it were 1.5 lbs, but that still sounds like a ton. There just isn't enough variety of flavors in it, it's all beef and beans - boring, if quite good.  I will give you that this is incredibly easy to make, and be sure you drain that fat. And now I have TONS of leftovers... oh boy.

text:
This was the first chili I have ever made, and I did make several changes to the original recipe.  First, I used lean ground turkey to make it a bit healthier.  I added 4 cloves of fresh minced garlic instead of garlic salt, and a sprinkle of coarse kosher salt. Tonight was my first time using my chopper machine and I must have done something wrong because the onion somehow pureed in the chopper. I still used it, it just made the chili less chunky.  However, I did add about 1/2 of a chopped green bell pepper.  Finally the last bit of difference is that I sprinkled a few sprinkles of Louisiana Hot Sauce in it to give it some heat.  I don't know if it's beginner's luck or what-- but it came out beyond perfect!

I make this at least once a month, and I never, ever have enough leftovers. I make it in the crock pot for at least 6 hours. Brown meat and onions and throw everything else in, stir and let cook! I use fresh garlic instead of garlic powder, hot chili seasoning, hot Pace Picante (about 2/3rds of the bottle), and a good dash of Tabasco. Add a little water if it's looking too thick. Perfect!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really love this recipe!  The first time I made it, I made it as written and it was really quite enjoyable- but I could see some adjustments I could make to suit my family and make it really shine at our Christmas Eve dinner.  So what I did the second time around was the following: I used one pound of hamburger and one pound of Jimmy Dean spicy sausage;  I used a whole large onion, and also several cloves of fresh minced garlic instead of the garlic salt; I replaced about half of the tomato sauce with Spicy V8 Juice; and I added a can of Rotel.  I cooked the chili the night before on the stove top, then let it meld overnight in the fridge and the next day I tossed it in the crock pot to simmer for a good part of the day before serving.  Finally, after tasting it, I opted to add a couple dashes of hot sauce, as we like our chili rather spicy.  My family REALLY loved this!  One of my favorite things about any chili recipe is how adaptable they are to personal tastes, and I am sure I will continue to play around with this one some more throughout the winter.  Thanks for a great recipe Deb!  It really is a winner, even without any changes  :)

text:
Okay, i have to admit at 1st i was skeptical...but then i made it yesterday and my hubby kept telling me how good this was (huge smile on my face) - best one i have ever made he said!  I like to read other reviews to see what needs tweaking before i try a recipe.  I did almost exactly as stated by Deb.  I just added chopped garlic to the onion and ground beef mix and i used a whole 16 oz jar of chunky salsa (Pace Medium) and then a can of mexican diced tomatoes vs. tomato sauce.  After cooking beef/onion and garlic i drained and put in crock pot over the beans and tomatoes.  then layered remaining ingredients w/1 tsp each of cumin and cayenne pepper.  Cooked on low for couple of hrs; turned it off and added 1 chopped green pepper and 1/2 red pepper.  stirred and let sit for 30 min.  I like my peppers al dente/crunchy.  Came out PERFECT!!!  i actually wish i had doubled the recipe!  Served over Ditalina pasta and my hubby likes to eat his over salad and/or with Fritos on top.  I think the package of chili seasoning mix, salsa and can of mexican tomatoes it what made it so much better than any other i have tried.  I am tossing out all other recipes and replacing with just this one.  Like Mac and Cheese recipes, I like to keep trying a bunch until i find one that i can perfect and call a keeper.  This is a DEFINITE keeper!  Would rate on scale of 1-10 - a 15!  Must make it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! This was a big hit and will be my permanent, "go-to" Chili recipe.  The salsa really IS the key to great flavor.  I used lean ground pork instead of beef, and I reduced the tomato sauce to 2 cups, making up for the the other 1/2 cup with beer, which I've always added to my chili.  In addition, I used the entire envelope of chili seasoning mix, and I used garlic POWDER instead of garlic salt, as the packaged mix and salsa already contain salt. Next time I might do the entire 12-oz. jar of salsa, but I wanted to use the suggested amount for the first attempt. I snipped some green onions (scallions) to sprinkle on top of each bowl to add a little color.  Heat level can be easily controlled by using MILD chili mix and MILD salsa. I used Medium for both, and might even ramp it up next time to HOT!  Thanks, Deb - this is definitely a keeper.

None
text:
My chili gets rave reviews but it takes a long time to prepare and tonight I was in a lazy mood so I thought I'd try this recipe because of all the great reviews. Hubby and nephew liked it well enough, but for me it was just okay. A little too tomato-y (even though I cut the tomato sauce to 2 cups and added a can of diced tomatoes) and super thick. I had to add beef broth to thin it out a little. I don't care for kidney beans so I used pinto, black and great northern beans. It had absolutely no kick and we like our food spicy, so I added a teaspoon of cayenne and a jalapeno. All in all I think this is a good springboard recipe.

Hope you reprint    Chili Mix   4 T chili powder  1 T crushed red pepper   1 T dried onion  1 T dried onion   2 tsp sugar  2 tsp cumin  2 tsp parsley  2 tsp salt   1 tsp basil  1/4 tsp pepper  Store in air tight container.  This is meant to go with the chili recipe

text:
Very good.  As mentioned in another review, it is a lot like Wendy's chili, but with more flavor and not mushy.  I used 93% lean hamburger, which came in a 2.25lb package (I used all of it), diced tomatoes instead of tomato sauce, and drained the "sauce" from the kidney beans, as well as drained the fat off the hamburger.  I added a cup of water since it seemed a little dry and I like it slightly soupy.

Serve up with some cornbread for an excellent meal!

text:
I made this a few days ago. This is an excellent recipe without a lot of fuss. I got rave reviews. I did make two slight changes. I used more chili seasoning then the recipe called for and I added a cube of chipolte seasoning. Other than that, I followed the recipe and this will be my go to recipe from now on. One thing I did notice was I thought my beef tasted a little bland so next time I think I will add some seasoning to the beef while browning. By the way, I made a double batch and it fed seven people with no leftovers.

text:
Used this recipe last night and it was a huge hit... with a couple of minor adjustments. I used a 16 oz. jar of salsa, added 3 cloves of fresh minced garlic, and 1 medium jalapeno pepper diced. I then split the recipe between 2 crock pots and in the 2nd one I added 4 more diced jalapenos and 2 tablespoons of habanero sauce to create "man chili" as my gang called it. It was HOT but delish! I served it with regular and jalapeno cheddar cornbread and they had a feast! Thanks so much for sharing!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fabulous, easy-fix chili recipe, just as written!  It can also easily be tweaked to suit one's taste. Since we like chili with NO beans, I omit the beans; use 1 lb. ground beef; 1.5 lbs. stew meat, chopped. I omit the garlic salt. Use 1 whole packet of McCormick Chili Seasoning; add 3 cloves fresh garlic. I add some beef broth (about 1/2 cup), strong brewed coffee (about 3/4 cup), 1 tbsp unsweetened cocoa; a dash of worcestershire sauce; 1 tbsp cumin and chili powder; 2 tbsp brown sugar. I think it's key to let it simmer (crockpot or stovetop) for 4+ hours for best flavor (best next day). My very picky DH loves this version of Deb's chili.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This is an awesome and super easy recipe! I kind of tweaked though because I didn't have everything in my pantry. I didn't have premade chili seansoning so I made my own chili seasoning with chili powder, cumin, oregano, salt, cayenne pepper, pinch of corriander, garlic powder, marjoram, and paprika. I had dark kidney beans, but I didn't have light kidney beans. I had ranch style beans with sliced jalepeno's which was an awesome substitute that I will probably use forever now! I also used a high quality organic lean ground beef which seriously is way more flavorful than the stuff in the plastic rounds. I didn't have tomato sauce either so I used tomato paste and made sauce out of it. And wow does mild pace picante make the biggest difference ever versus your plain diced tomatos! My husband said this was the best beef chili that  I have ever made and it was so easy. He wants me to make this every week now. Awesome recipe! this will def be a staple dinner in my house!

text:
This chili recipe is amazing!  I have made it a number of times, and have made minor changes that make it taste even better in my opinion.  I use 2-3 pounds of ground turkey and use two full packages of chili seasoning.  I also cut down on the tomato sauce and increase the salsa.  I use a 14 oz container of rojos restaurant style salsa as well along with a 12 oz - 16 oz container of salsa verde with tomatillos and cilantro.  I also add 1 tablespoon of brown sugar. Yum!!

text:
I made this yesterday because it was a rainy/overcast day, and a little cool.  I wanted to make chili that wasn't complicated but tasted great.  I have my own recipe that has a LOT of ingredients, but I didn't feel like doing all the work.  I stumbled on this recipe and gave it a shot.  Seriously... outstanding! I followed the recipe with no changes, other than that I simmered it in a crock pot for about 4 hours on high.  To me, it tastes like chili should! My mom used to make a recipe that tasted very similar - over the years she changed her recipe and I didn't like the results.  This is like am homage to my childhood :)  And quite honestly, I like it better than my complicated concoction.  Perfection!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/67449.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is easy, tasty chili.  I've made it three times now.

I used the same ingredients just more of everything.  A whole onion, 2 cans of light and 2 cans of dark kidney beans, 15oz jar of salsa, 28oz can of crushed tomatoes (instead of sause), real garlic, two packages of chili seasoning (1 mild, 1 hot).  The extra salsa and extra crushed tomatoes made it a little soupier than I would have liked so next time I will hold back a little on both.

The only thing I did differently was I sauteed the onions, then added the garlic, then put in the meat and the chili seasoning so the meat could cook with the spices.  Then added everything else in and let it simmer.  I've tried it with ground beef and ground turkey.  Both were good, however I like the beef better.

It was a little sweet and I'm not sure where the sweetness is coming from.  I like a different tasting chili, but because this recipe is fast and easy it ends up winning.

text:
This is the BEST chili!  I think those who rated it low added salsa instead of pace picante SAUCE.....depending how hot you like your chili, Pace comes anywhere from mild to hot.  I also slightly decreased the amount of beans.  And I also cook this one day ahead of time and let it sit in the fridge all night to really soak in the flavors.  I then put it in the crockpot about two hours before serving.  YUM - Thanks Deb!!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-02-04T13:28:56.24
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
7671041
Display Name:
hypertrophy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
190
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
- Used whole large onion instead of half, figuring I had no other use for it.  Worked out fine.
- Used relatively lean ground beef, but kept the grease in the chili.
- Used significantly more pepper and garlic, it was good but probably _not_ necessary.
- Used pure garlic powder instead of garlic salt because my store brand chili seasoning contains salt, unlike the williams brand used by the author.  *No additional salt was needed*
- Used 1 can (around 1.75 cups) of tomato sauce and a 15oz jar of medium-spice salsa (about the same total liquid but more of it from the salsa), because that was what was available.  Excellent.
- Used whole packet (just under 2x) chili seasoning.  It wasn't too much but was certainly more than necessary.
- Used the prescribed beans plus a can of black beans (was looking for pinquito/pinto but didn't find any) - was worried that the black bean would be too tough but it was great.
- Used pressure cooker - 15 psi for 20 minutes (starting from full pressure) and natural release.  Ended up spending forever trying to remove the stuck lid but it worked great, perfectly moist and tender.

I like a thick chili but was concerned, especially with my extra dry ingredients, that I'd too little liquid, but at least in the pressure cooker it was absolutely perfect - thick, but with enough liquid remaining to be a real chili (not chili-flavored-casserole or whatever)

FWIW my adjustments were mainly about convenience, habit, or nutrition-density - not necessity.

text:
GREAT BASIC CHILI !
I am reminded of the story of the guy who was going to WIN the Texas Chili Cook-off when a competitor stopped the judges from giving him the award for BEST CHILI until they heard HOW he made the CHILI.
The guy DID NOT bring any ingredients, but visited EACH cook-off contestant and collected a sample and dumped them all in a pot. He had a great tasting chili ( best of the best).
So I took out my cook-books and highlighted all MY FAVORITE INGREDIENTS to add to my chili.
Chili is like pizza. ANY FAVORITE INGREDIENT can be added for layers of flavor.
I like Deddoozie's chili. I would for sure add some brown sugar and garlic in small amounts.
People who do not like beans can remove them and add sausage or steak chunks and/or chopped celery. Extra tomatoes and onion are always good too.

The taste was outstanding BUT the chili was SO HOT so next time I'll use Pace medium picante.  I also used chili beans instead of kidneys, which is my personal preference. userID:
5833917
Display Name:
Jacolyn 
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2374460.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband asked me to make chili for tailgating at an Army/UCONN football game at West Point here in NY.  Everyone loved this!  It went very quickly!  I followed the advice of others and used 1 (10oz) can of diced tomatoes w/ green chile peppers, 1 jar corn, a little more than 1 (14oz) jar of tomato sauce, a half jar of chunky salsa (couldn't find Pace at my local grocery store), oregano, paprika, basil, and sugar, in addition to the pepper.  I used onion powder in place of the chopped onions and left out the beans, because my husband doesn't like chili with beans.  I browned the meat (half beef and half Johnsonville sausage) with some sauteed, finely-chopped garlic and put everything into my slow cooker on low overnight.  Oh, and I also mixed in a bit of cinnamon (just enough to compliment the meat) and also bacon bits.  Served it with shredded cheddar on the top.  They ate it all!  I didn't even get to try any, because the tailgaters had 2nds and 3rds!

text:
This was REALLY good.  I took the advice of other readers and added basil, oregano, sugar, paprika and garlic powder to the recipe.  I also used one can of stewed tomato's (and basil) and 1/2 cup tomato sauce (instead of 2 1/2 can sauce).  I used about 10 oz of salsa (instead of 8) and used 4 tbls of taco seasoning mix (instead of chili seasoning, because I didn't have any). After the meat was browned I put it in the crockpot for 2 and 1/2 hours.  Then I put the whole thing over pasta and sprinkled it with chedder cheese.  Amazing!!!

WOW...The EASIEST & ABSOLUTE BEST CHILI I HAVE EVER HAD AND MADE!!!!  I threw this together in no time with ingredients I had on hand, and am SO impressed!!!!  Everyone LOVED it!  I doubled the recipe and used less chili powder and beans because of my elderly parents who live with me.  I had a really mild marinara sauce on hand and used that for the "tomato sauce", and I also used 1 can of rotel tomatoes w/ green chilies along with the Pace Picante Sauce, It was still fabulous and I can see that you can easily adapt this recipe to your taste or use it just as it....it couldn't be better!!!!  Thank you, Debdoozie!!!!!!!  This is my new permanent go-to chili recipe!!!!  LOVE IT!!!!!!

text:
I'm not a big chili eater, but I was bored and wanted to try something other then poultry and steak recipes.   I followed the recipe pretty closely and found that it was a little bitter when I tasted it. I added the other half of that 1/2 of tomato sauce, a little adobo seasoning and a little honey.  After I did all of that my chili came out tasting EXACTLY like the chili they give you at Wendy's (mind you, that's the only chili i ever eat). I was really delighted by that. Made some cornbread muffins and white rice. Tomorrow, with the left overs, I think I'll make a taco salad. Great recipe! Easy too!

text:
I'm not a big cook but we had a chili contest at work today so I used this recipe and it was the favorite.  I like the ease of the recipe and I made a few rookie changes to it.  I used 1 lb. of ground beef and 1 lb. of pork sausage.  I only used 1 3/4 cups of tomato sause (that was the size of the can) so I used 16 oz. of salsa.  Put is a little more garlic salt and some cajun seasoning.  It needed a bit more liquid so in goes a can of Bud Light.  I should have had another can today as a fair amount of liquid was absorbed overnight so water had to do today.  A little cayanne and it was complete.  $75- first prize is mine!!

text:
Best chili recipe I've had and the only chili recipe I ever use. I've made this exactly as written but over the years I have tweaked it a bit.   I saute 3 cloves of chopped garlic and bell pepper along with the onions. I use one can kidney beans and one can pinto beans.  I use Herdez medium because I'm not a big fan of pace. Herdez is more authentic.  Topped with shredded cheddar, chopped jalapeos, sour cream and green onions.  
 Delish!

text:
mmmmm delicious!  It was by far the most simple recipe for chili I've made, I usually go for the complicated ones with 20 ingredients but was feeling lazy.  I'm glad I was!  I'm using this one from now on.  The only thing I did different was to use 1/2 ground turkey and 1/2 turkey italian sausage (hot), and I added an extra can of beans because I like thick chili.  It was a bit salty (even though I used garlic powder instead of garlic salt), so I think next time I will make my own chili seasoning mix with less sodium.  I can't wait to eat this tomorrow!!!!  Thanks for a great recipe, Deb.  UPDATE: I made it again with all ground turkey and no extra beans...I used homemade chili seasoning mix that I didn't put much salt in, and that remedied the salt problem.  Excellent and EASY!

text:
This was even a hit with my fussy 3 year old!  I used mild salsa and it was absolutely delicious.  I made my own chili seasoning because I couldn't find it at the store:  2 tbsp. chili powder 1 tbsp. seasoned salt 2 tsp. cumin 1 tsp. oregano 1 tsp. salt 1 tsp. onion powder 1/2 tsp. garlic powder  I added pureed sweet potatoes at the end (my son had no idea) and served it with brown rice -- made a really well balanced meal.

text:
Very easy and very tasty. I substituted the ground beef for "ground beef" made out of veggie crumbles. I used two 12-ounce packages (typically found refrigerated in the produce department) and it turned out fantastic. The veggie crumbles don't need to "brown" for ten minutes, so begin by sauteing the onions for 6-8 minutes and then throw in the "ground beef." I also made the Blue Corn Cornbread recipe from this site to accompany- amazing!

text:
Delicious! I was skeptical of making this chili because of the few ingredients - it sounded too easy to be tasty. But I was pleasantly surprised. Here are some modifications I made: Used ground chicken instead of beef, used fresh chopped garlic and sprinkling of salt instead of garlic salt, added 1 t.coriander, 1/8 t. chili powder, 1/2 t. cumin and 1/4 t. red pepper flakes, added 1/4 chopped green pepper, used entire envelope of chili seasoning. I am so excited to have found this recipe and plan to make it on chilly winter nights in the future.

text:
Not sure why this recipe gets rave reviews.  I followed it to a tee (but added cubed beef) and it wasn't flavorful at all.  So, I decided to add the following and it came out just perfect:  1 cup of strong brewed coffee, 1 tablespoon of cocoa powder, extra 8 oz of salsa, 1 tablespoon of ground cumin, 4 extra tablespoons of chili seasoning mix.  It makes a huge batch that only lasted our family 2 days.  I give the revised recipe 5 stars.

I've never made chili before. text:
I've been looking for a really good chili recipe for some time and I finally found it! This IS the EASIEST and BEST tasting chili I've made yet!! I followed the recipe except for a few changes, I added diced green pepper with the ground beef and onion. And as many suggested I added one large can of crushed tomatoes instead of tomato sauce. I also added one can of DelMonte diced tomatoes (garlic & onion with the liquid). I did use "Williams Original Chili seasoning" (found it on line), and "Pace" medium salsa. The only thing that wasn't clear to me in this recipe is if I should drain the beans or not. I decided to drain most of the liquid off before adding the beans. This recipe has been added to my favorite, and I will definitely be making it again and again. My search is over THANK YOU Deb!!!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the second time I made this basic chili for a competition and the second time I won.  I did make my own customizations to the recipe but I think it would have won anyway without my changes. I added 3 cloves crushed garlic to beef/onion mix. I used diced tomatoes instead of sauce to make a chunky chili.  I used 4 cans of the diced tomatoes and 2 cans diced green chilies. I used two cans of pinto beans and 1 can of red kidney beans. I made my own chili mix from a recipe on this site.  I added 2-4 T of maple syrup (I don't like sugar) which I think is important to cut the acid flavor in the tomatoes and I used 2 jars of salsa, one mild and one medium.  I added salt as needed, and it was needed. This filled my 6 quart crockpot.  One hour before the end of cooking time I added three diced bell peppers, one red, one yellow and one orange.  This makes it look beautiful and adds that winning touch!

I just made this, it's simmering now, and my preliminary review is VERY GOOD!  I imagine it will only get better with time. The only thing I might add is some diced jalapeo to brighten things up, but so far the chili is tasting really good. Thanks, Deb!

text:
Simple and tasty! I love the use of salsa (you can pick a really good gourmet salsa if you like to experiment) and it adds great flavour. I usually make it with a can of dark red kidney beans and a can of baked beans. I have also been known to add a few carrots and a bit of spinach (pureed of course) to it so my kids would get their veggies in - the chili hides these wonderfully. I top it with grated cheese and a spoon of sour cream. The kids love it and my hubby adds his hot sauce and it still tastes great. Well done Debdoozie!!

text:
I really enjoyed this!  This is the best home-made chili I've ever made.  And it was soooo simple to make.  The only thing I had a problem with was the american measurements (I'm from Toronto, Canada), so I just added: 1 large jar of salsa, 1 jar of tomato sauce (spaghetti sauce) and 1 full can of stewed tomatoes.  I also added a packet and a third of chili powder, since I added much more sauce than suggested.  I also diced some green and red pepper and added it to the mix.

text:
This recipe is EXCELLENT! Perfect blend of flavor.  Beats any canned chili I've tried. I wouldn't add or subtract anything. My only suggestion for those who don't like "Spicy" is that they buy mild chili seasoning. I brought a brand that didn't specify whether it was hot, medium or mild and our chili turned out to be quite HOT. I love this recipe and my husband is already asking me to make more and freeze it for his lunches. Yummy!!!!

text:
Excellent chili and easy to make!! I browned meat and onions the night before, then, added all ingredients in crockpot in AM and came home to yummy dinner!! I used one can of sauce and one can of dice tomatoes. (It didn't come out soupy but had a little bit of liquid...which we like.) I also made my own chili seasoning (b/c I forgot it at the store). I used the Chili Seasoning Mix II from this site but without the flour and did not use the dried onion or garlic (I put both in the ground beef). I also did not add very much red pepper since I have 2 small kids and didn't want it too spicy! This was a great Halloween evening meal!! Thanks!!

This was delicious! I did change a few things. I used 1 lb. ground turkey, 1 can light red pinto beans and one dark, 1 can of chili beans, I can of diced tomatoes with spices, a packet of chili seasoning, and added a whole onion and lots of garlic. Oh and the cup of salsa. The extra spices in the beans and tomatoes made it pretty spicy but it was still delicious, thick and flavorful!

text:
Wish I could give this more stars than just 5...I've never made chili before (I'm 25 and just recently married so I'm experimenting more with different stuff).  I'm not a huge fan of chili, but I won my office chili cookoff out of 17 different chilis that were entered.  I added some extras, but followed the recipe for the most part.  If you like it a little spicier then I siggest adding a half can of the Rotel HOT and alot of extra cayenne, chili powder, and the chili seasoning packet.  I also cut up Cajun Andouille sausage and everyone seemed to like that.  This is a great recipe though and it is very impressive if you want to show off a little.

We *love* this chili!  The only things I change are to use garlic powder instead of garlic salt, and ground turkey instead of beef.  I make my own chili seasoning instead of commercial packets.  I have doubled, tripled, and even quadrupled this recipe to serve large crowds of teenagers, and men watching football.  Everyone raves.  Can't understand the folks who didn't like it.  And it's so easy!  It's been a lifesaver when it's my turn to host Teen Lunch :)

userID:
1722839
Display Name:
Peas with Honey
isPro:
False
followersCount:
8

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think my chili quest might be over!  I used about 1.5 lbs. ground beef and 1 lb. ground turkey.  I opted for mild salsa because my two year old is in a stage where he thinks even cookies are "spicy" for some weird reason, but added a few liberal splashes of Texas Pete to my bowl before eating.  I added some additional garlic powder, chili powder, etc., as the one spice packet didn't quite give it enough kick (but I used extra meat).  I also didn't know whether or not to drain the beans, as it doesn't say in the directions.  I did NOT drain them, but next time I will.  This is a versatile chili, and I can envision adding lots of extra veggies, lentils, grains, or other meat "stretchers" which would take this meal even farther.  I thought salsa in chili sounded so weird, but I'm glad I tried it!  As it was cooking, I didn't think it was all that spectacular, but after about an hour of simmering (and the extra spices), this really came together.  Everyone gobbled it down.  We served it with a choice of tortilla chips, cornbread, saltine crackers, sharp cheddar, and sour cream.  Soooo yummy I can't wait to get hungry again! :)  My only changes next time would be to use my own spice blend, as I try to stay away from the packet version of things like that (but in a pinch, it was still good!)

text:
This is the best chili recipe ever.  The only thing I changed was I didn't add the beans because my family doesn't care for beans.  This chili is amazing.  I used another user's suggestion of Pace Picante Salsa.  I debated between medium and mild and went with medium.  It gave the chili hotness but not too much.  You won't need another chili recipe after trying this one.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
I have made this twice now. The first time I made exactly as the recipe called for. The second time I was making it for a crowd and was concerned about the spice level so I excluded the garlic salt and black pepper. I made my own chili seasoning mix from another recipe on this website which may have made the difference in the needed seasoning. Got rave reviews both times and will never make chili any other way. I used Costco's medium organic salsa. YUM!

text:
This is actually the recipe my father has used for years. However, I have made my own changes that I thought I would list here.  I love spicy chili so I substitute one lb of the hamburger for one lb of hot sausage, I have never really cared for kidney beans so instead I use one can of hot chili beans and one can of mild chili beans and I swear by the generic chili beans you can buy at Save-a-lot!  I also use one can of Rotel tomato and green chillies and one can of diced fire roasted tomatoes and this is in addition to the salsa.  I have won a few contests with this recipe and everyone loves it!  Have fun and add whatever you want!

Great basic chili, and ridiculously easy! I used one can of dark kidney beans and one can of pinto beans. I also added a can of Ro-Tel tomatoes & green chiles, 1/2 a can of yellow corn, extra garlic, and used hot chili seasoning mix.   It would be TOUGH to mess up this recipe! Give it a shot! My man took a double batch to a party at work and didn't have ANY left to bring home. Thanks Deb!

text:
the way a person likes thier chili is very different from one individual to another, I think. But this is a great simple recipe. I've made lots of chili recipes, and I find the complicated ones just aren't worth the time at all. The only thing lacking is diced tomatoes, but I made the recipe exactly - figuring I could change it once I tasted it. But it doesn't need any changes, I really like it without the tomatoes. I used Pace salsa (will try a better brand next time, I'm not a fan of Pace, but figured I should stick to the recipe) and McCormick Chili seasoning. I'll be making this in the crock pot frequently this winter!

text:
I gave this 4 stars based on being a great starting point, but I think the yummy factor really depends on the type of salsa and chili seasoning you use.  Whatever combo I used was yummy.  However, I did doctor it up with a variety of spices to add some heat. I think next time I will blend some chipotle chiles and mix it with an additional can of tomato sauce instead of the salsa though.  I wanted more flavor and more of a kick.  Anyway, this is how I served it:  I baked potatoes, cut them in half, and carved out a bit of the middle.  Then I filled the potatoes with chili and covered it with cheddar cheese and green onions. I plopped the potatoe on a hearty  ladel full of chili on a plate, and then sprinkled a good handful of fritos on top. I had sour cream and jalepenos on the side as extras.  This meal was gobbled up.  5 stars all around from my mom, dad, and husband.

Yesterday was having company for dinner and cards, looked for an easy chili recipe and chose this one having read the reviews. Scaled it up a bit as I wanted to be left with some for today, I think there's some kind of football event on this afternoon. lol As had been noted by others easy to substitute a bit based on what's on hand, but I tried to stay close or I'm not actually making this recipe am I and then why offer a review or comments? Anyway, I used a 14 0z. can each of light red kidney , pinto and chili beans, ( a mix). Used Scarpone's Strained Tomatoes in place of the tomato sauce, also used Herdez mild salsa and added a small can of diced mild green chili's and one of salsa verde. If this was just for me I would have used a spicier salsa, but laid off doing so, not knowing my guests tolerance for heat. Therefore, offered assorted hot sauces on the table. Served over rice, and the ladies brought a nice salad, assorted buns and squares and sorbet for dessert. The ladies all loved this and said so, and then proceeded to kick my butt at cards. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
This was the best chili I've ever made - I had some friends over for a party, and the only problem was - I didn't anticipate everyone going back for 2nd & 3rd helpings, and so we nearly ran out.  Some of the changes I made: I added a can of diced tomatoes (drained), 1 TBS. of minced garlic, a couple dashes of hot pepper sauce, and I had to make my own chili seasoning mix because I didn't have any.  I found a great mix recipe on this site that included flour, basil, salt, pepper, paprika, white & brown sugar, oregano, cumin & crushed red pepper - and made my own instead of using a store-bought chili seasoning.  Otherwise, there was really nothing that I changed.  I think the salsa is the key to this recipe.  It was wonderful, and I will use this every time I make chili.  Thank you!

Wow, even a newbee like me could make tasty chili. My husband and daugter always complain my chili is too bland, so they were ready to get the chili powder and pepper out, well, I told them to try it before they sprinkled anything on it, no one used any spices. We put a slice of american cheese in it right before we ate it in our bowl.

text:
This chili is delicious! I was looking for a chili close to mine, but that had the little extra something I was missing. Salsa and Williams seasoning was it! I halved the meat (used 1 pack veggie crumbles) and used 1 pack of Williams seasoning. I further followed Deb's advice and used 8 oz of Pace Picante Sauce, medium. Instead of 2.5 cups tomato sauce, I used 1 can tomato sauce and 1 can diced tomatoes, pinto in place of kidney beans, and some garlic. These were minor changes and the recipe is just about foolproof! I highly recommend making this yummy chili - tweaked or not! And of course, like most chilis, this is even better the day after. Thanks for the wonderful recipe Deb!

text:
I tried this recipe because I needed a simple recipe w/out too many ingredients for my son's boy scout campout.  I made a test batch at home and thought it was really tasty; for his campout, he cooked the beef and onions first, then drained and cooled it, and mixed w/ salsa so he wouldn't have to take a glass jar camping.  Then at camp, he mixed the meat w/ the other ingredients and simmered for a while.  Well, his chili pleased his patrol very much (they ate it w/ Fritos scoops, grated cheddar, and sour cream.  Then the older scouts and the grownups came over to get in on the action!  This is a great kid-friendly recipe -- you can adjust the heat w/ your choice of salsa and chili seasoning.  We used Safeway Select Chipotle Salsa (and I added some ground chipotle powder to the batch I made for my family).  This recipe is a keeper!

text:
Warning!  If you like your chili spicy, this is the recipe for you.  I enjoyed this chili the way I prepared it, but would have found it too hot if I had made it exactly as written.  I cut the amount of ground black pepper in half and used mild Pace Picante Sauce instead of medium or hot.  Be sure to read Deb's additional advice (currently listed as the most helpful review) in which she recommends using Williams Chili Seasoning and Pace Picante Sauce.  This is a great recipe that you can easily tweak to suit your own taste.  Thanks Deb.

text:
This was fabulous..the best and easiest chili I have ever made! Based on other reviews I of course had some additions. While browning the meat, I added a whole onion with some garlic. To the chili, I added 1 can (15oz) of pinto beans, a whole (16oz) jar of salsa, and 1 (15oz) can of diced tomatoes with green chiles. To spice it up, I added ceyenne pepper, oregano, basil, and brown sugar. My coworkers all raved!

text:
Good recipe to be sure, I use it as a base and add for my tastes.

I always add a tablespoon or two of brown sugar to chili and lasagne sauces it cuts the acidity of the tomatos.

Also I highly recommend getting an assortment of peppers ( chili, habenaro, jalopena, pablona, and even red and yellow for color ) based on your tastes and chopping them up ( I use a food chopper ) and adding them in.

I also make mine with 3-4 cans of beans ( add black, red and/or northern and it comes out just great.

text:
This is a wonderful chili recipe! I've never thought to add a whole jar of salsa to my chili and it was great! My all time fav salsa is Meijer gold brand Roasted Black Bean & Corn.. went so well with chili. Another tip for all of you out there who like natural products. Williams Original Chili seasoning is all natural. No MSG's, no salt, preservatives or fillers. This is the best chili seasoning ever! I have only found this product at Super Target and make a special trip just  for it. I altered the recipe and put a little extra chili seasoning and beef stock for more juice without it it was really thick. Just a preference of mine. Try this recipe and you'll be hooked!

Wow - my husband isn't a big chili fan, but I made this for him, and he loved it.  The only changes I made, was that I didn't have a thick salsa, so I chopped up a tomato and green pepper to add to it.  I only used 1 Tbsp. chili powder since my Norwegian palate is opposed to thigs too spicy.  And finally, I used ground venison since that is what I had thawed at the time.  Topped with a little shredded cheese and sour cream, and served it with the Golden Cornbread from this site.  This is going into my supper rotation!

text:
I just won a chili cookoff!  I tried a couple different chili recipes before chosing this one, because I didn't think a recipe as simple as this would work, but it did.  I changed a few things, by only using one pound of ground beef (after I won, everyone wanted to try it, so I should have stuck with the two pounds.) I also added 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper and a whole package of French's "Chili-O" chili seasoning mix.I only added three cans of tomato sauce and I added a can of diced tomatos. I also added 3 tablespoons of Cumin. (My supervisor thinks I won because of the three tablespoons of Cumin, used under her advice!)  I used Pace Picante sauce.  People were putting it on their hotdogs because they said it was good for chili dogs.  Thanks for the recipe!  It's the first time I've ever been in a chili cookoff.

text:
Thought this was a great chili.  Taking advice from previous reviewers, I used one can chopped tomatoes and one (15oz)can tomato sauce instead of all tomato sauce.  I increased the onion and added one tablespoon of sugar to even out the tomato base.  I also substituted canned, hot chili beans, including the sauce, for one of the cans of kidney beans and it really kicked it up to the right temperature...not too hot, but certainly not bland.  Served with Trader Joe's cornbread, which is out of this world.  Thanks for the recipe, Deb.

Very very tasty.... it's also very versatile.  I've worked with this chili for months and have made modifications such as doubling the amounts of tomato sauce/ salsa, adding homemade salsa, adding cilantro, doubling the onion, adding tomatoes... you really can do anything with this recipe!  I think it tastes better with my little add-ins.  Without it, I think it is too much like Spaghetti Sauce.  But it is a great base recipe, work with it and add to it and make it one your family will love.

text:
This chili is the tastiest chili I have ever had - bar none!  I am not a very good cook, but can follow a recipe.  It was easy and fast.  I love this chili.
I made a couple of modifications to the recipe.  I replaced some ground beef with Jimmy Dean Italian Sausage.  Where it asks for chili seasoning, I added Texas brand Chili seasoning.  I put in a mild salsa.  It still had a kick to it, but it was the perfect balance of taste and heat.
I highly recommend this recipe because it provides enough lattitude to craft it to your liking.

text:
This chili was delicious, and so easy to make! My kitchen smelled heavenly! 

I did make a few modifications. First of all, I halved the recipe (and still had a lot of leftovers...but not because it didn't taste good!) but I still used 1/2 an onion. When browning the beef and onion I also threw in a tablespoon of minced garlic. I used a roasted garlic flavor salsa, and to make it even spicier I used the entire package of chili seasoning mix. I only used one can of beans - I opted for the dark kidney beans. I also threw in a can of corn. The chili was definitely hot and spicy! We had it on top of rice.  OH! I totally forgot to add some cheese. Next time! I'll definitely make this again!

text:
I thought this was a great recipe!  The changes I made due to what I had on hand in the house:  1 can diced tomatoes, 1 can tomato sauce, 1 can sweet corn, 1 diced red pepper, 1 diced yellow pepper, 1 16oz jar Newman's Own Salsa (medium), 1 teaspoon cumin, garlic powder instead of garlic salt.  I only simmered for 20 minutes.  It was great. (I know I changed it all up but I couldn't help myself!)  My boys aged 4 and 7 ate it right down with a glop of sour cream and some shredded cheddar on top with corn muffins on the side.  My husband ate 2 ladlefuls in the first bowl and said "that went down too fast!" and got up for seconds.    :)

text:
I've tried a dozen different recipes.  Some of them were as simple as throwing two cans and a chunk of meat in a pot, while others called for 20 different ingredients including stuff like unsweetened cocoa which no one has in their cupboard, beer, coffee, every single herb and spice fresh from the dirt, 300 different types of meat, 7,000 different beans  and then simmer it until you retire and give it to your children as a graduation present. Any subtle omission or superfluous inclusion completely destroys the dish and you would be better off eating dog food.

Therefore, until I found this recipe, I stuck with the most basic method. It always comes out tasting decent and it takes next to no time and effort. Sometimes I'dd throw in a can of green chiles, maybe use a different bean or an uncased sausage if I was feeling dangerous.

The first time I tried this recipe I realized I had been living a lie. I didn't have to settle for good-not-great chili or spend hours in the kitchen with 1,000 ingredients. Some sort of magic happens with the salsa and the tomato juice. It gives the chili this certain bright tangyness that doesn't at all overshadow the deeper flavors and  overwhelm you. The only real problem is that it's hard stop eating it.

Now this Chili's not going to work with everyone. Some like their chili extremely thick, while this one's a bit thinner. It doesn't have a bitterness from coffee or cocoa or whtever which some might find disappointing. There aren't a ton of dif

This is a good idea... However I found that the bottled salsa left me with watery jous. You have nailed the consistency of the meat however I would suggest not cooking down the salsa. TOMATO are still a fit that should be treated very delicately so don't allow it to break down too much or you will lose the nutritional and sweetness factors in your dish. IT WILL BREAK!!!

text:
Being a poor college student who only recently converted to the "cooking every meal you eat" lifestyle, this recipe was amazing. The first thing that drew me to it was how wonderfully few ingredients it needed, and the simplicity of the ones it did need. The next was how simple it was, 2 steps, not much prep time, only one dirty pot, and food enough to last we almost a week? That's a winner in my book even if the recipe doesn't taste incredible (which this definitely does). Even more amazing, after I failed to use my common sense and burned the bejeezus out of the bottom of the pot by not stirring the chili at all while it was simmering, the chili STILL TASTED AMAZING (once the kitchen stopped smelling like smoke). Basically, this chili is disaster proof. I highly recommend it.

text:
This recipe is OK. Nothing bad about it -- just turns out this is not the way I like my chili. I did stick to the recipe.  I like the idea of using salsa and I used one with roasted poblano peppers in it.  I may try salsa in my chili again but not this recipe.  Everyone has different preferences and chili is a great example of how different our tastes can be regarding a particular dish. I see where someone even likes mushrooms in their chili. :) For me, there was too much tomato sauce and not enough heat.  I now know I much prefer tomatoes in my chili and only a little tomato sauce if I use it at all.  This Texas cook also likes my chili with a lot more hot chili pepper flavor.

text:
Just made this chili last night.  My entire family of very picky eaters loved it!  It couldn't be any easier.  I pretty much followed the instructions, taking the advice of the recipe owner and using Pace Salsa (med) and 2 entire packages of chili seasoning mix (McCormick's).  I ended up using about 3 cups of tomato sauce (was using up the entire large can).  I also drained the kidney beans before adding.  We topped this with cheddar cheese and ate it with cornbread on a rainy evening.  This is my new favorite chili recipe - thanks Deb!!

text:
I have made this recipe a lot. It really is good! I think that the reason people have said that it's too hot without much flavor is that they added chili seasoning not a chili seasoning MIX. That would change the flavor a lot. The reason I think that is that I almost did the same thing. I almost did that because mix is on the next line and I just read it quickly saw chili seasoning. I also didn't know that packets even existed until this recipe. :) My mom always made it from scratch but hers is different than my husband is used to so I looked for a recipe that he'd like. And this was it!! If you don't have a packet on hand, someone suggested using Chili Seasoning Mix II from this site. It has all the same spices as the packet. Again, this has great flavor and smells wonderful while it's cooking. Thank you for the awesome recipe!!!

text:
Above Average!!  Love chili and am always trying new recipes.  Didn't have my usual ingredients and found this recipe.  When made as is too much tomato flavor for me (and I love tomatoes).  Second time I made it I replaced tomato sauce w/1 can rotelle and 1 can whole tomatoes, used Chili Seasoning Mix II from this site minus 1/2 the flour and sugar in that recipe, the rest of ingredients as is plus some beef broth to thin it out a little.  OMG! It was awesome.  Family of 5, no left overs.  Made the Homesteader Cornbread (from this site) which was excellent.  Serve chili w/sour cream, chopped onions and jalepenos and wedge of lime.

text:
This chili is AMAZING. I'm one of those people who usually loves recipes with 87 different steps, crazy ingredients and no shortcuts, but I can't stop making this chili. I tweaked it only slightly but it's still amazing as-is; I can't believe how easy it is, and how much tastier it is than other recipes that take way longer! So many people have asked me for this recipe. My (small) changes/specifications are as follows: 

for the tomato sauce, I used 29oz (a little over 3 1/2c) instead of 2 1/2c ... 1 pint of fresh tomato sauce from freshdirect, and one 15oz can of hunt's tomato sauce.

I also added 2tbs muscavado sugar.

Everything else is the same! 

For the salsa I used Paul Newman, and for the chili spice I used the freshdirect brand.

This chili is AWESOME! My husband's response was "is this REALLY the first time you've ever made chili??". I made some very small changes based on recommendations from previous reviewers, and it was DELICIOUS!

I added a 1/2 teaspoon sugar, a teaspoon salt, 5 tablespoons of the chili seasoning (rather than 4), and just a DASH of hot sauce. 

Thanks for this recipe! I will definitely be making it again!

SweetGem

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/754208.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome chili!! I got alot of compliments. 
For the salsa I like using Tostido's brand-Medium. I don't like things too spicy and the medium is perfect once it simmers down. 
From some of the other reviews, I substituted the light kidneys with pinto. I added 1 can of tom paste and 1 can of 'diced tomatoes with pepper and onions'. 
I would skip the garlic salt and pepper on this recipe next time b/c the chili seasoning which I got from this site, I made myself and it covered those ingredients. As a result, I found I had to add a bit more sugar to it to cut some of saltiness out.
I left it in the slow cooker for a few hours and served it over rice with the cornbread that I also got from this site. Sprinkled the top with shredded cheese and a dollop of sour cream and I fed 5 adults with no left overs!!
