text:
Yep. It's excellent chili! Thanks. Here is what I used just because it's what I had on hand:
Browned chuck roast cut up in small pieces and chopped garlic. Added 2 cans kidney beans, 1 can Ranch style pinto beans, 1 can Rotel with green chilies, 1 can El Pato (hot), black pepper, chili powder (Gebhardt's becasue I was out of New Mexico which is my favorite) and a cup of Pace Picante hot salsa. Simmered for a few hours. Delicious!! My son is a very picky eater, especially regarding chili and he said it was EXCELLENT!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy and so good! I used about 12 oz of paces picante sauce mild since I don't really like spicy chili. I used one pound of ground pork and one pound of larger cut ground beef so it stayed chunkier. And I followed other reviewers recommendations, and used a can of tomato sauce and a can of tomatoes (I used the fire roasted diced tomatoes!). I will definitely use this recipe again, even the kids ate some and asked for more. I think this would be a great work potluck also, since you could brown the meat and onions the night before and just open everything day of and put in crockpot.(oh yeah, I put it in crockpot on low for about 4 hours while I was running errands). Now that I think of it, chili is often better on the second day, maybe you could make it the day before and just put it on warm at work until lunchtime?

text:
Anytime I use salsa in a recipe, I try to make sure I actually like the salsa first. This time I used Herdez Salsa Ranchera without trying it.  The flavor was good but still overpowering. Next time I will use El Pato sauce, which I think my turkey would have a better chance of standing up to.  That said, it is an excellent, simple recipe, and with the proper tweabook for my tastes, it would easily reach five stars in my book.

text:
Delicious -- my two children loved it and my wife thought it was better than the one she usually purchases at a local diner. I added an extra can of dark red kidney beans to balance it out. It was a hit for our household. Another small adjustment was that I substituted fresh cloves of garlic instead of garlic salt. You can also add cayenne pepper or crushed red pepper flakes for a little kick. I served this to a crowd during Christmas -- everyone loved it !!

text:
My entire family enjoyed this recipe. It was quick & easy to prepare. The only change I made was to use fresh garlic cloves (4) because we were out of garlic salt.  One comment I would like to add is that this chili has just a hint of heat. It wasn't a problem for us, but I was planning on making this for someone recovering from surgery (to have in the freezer), but they cannot tolerate any "bite" in their food, so the chili powder will have to be reduced in the next batch.  This is in no way a criticism of the recipe.

country:
None
text:
This is hands down the best chili recipe EVER!!! My boyfriend can't get enough of this. You can really adjust the flavors to your personal taste with seasonings, without altering the original recipe. My bf is an avid hunter so I use deer meat instead of ground beef. I add an extra 4 oz. of tomato sauce and salsa, and also add in a bit more onion than called for and some minced garlic. This really conceals the flavor of the deer meat and no one I have ever served this to can believe it is deer! Bf even had me make it for his company picnic, and I won a chili cook off contest with it- with the deer meat! If your man likes to hunt, you will LOVE this recipe! And if he doesn't, you'll still love this recipe! Thanks for sharing Debbie!

text:
So simple, so versatile.  I've been making this recipe for yrs.  I've done so many things to it and it always comes out tasting great!  I've used a whole jar of salsa vs only half.  I've subbed cans of tomato soup in place of the tomato sauce.  I've used 2 pkgs of chili seasoning mix for an extra kick.  You CAN'T mess up this recipe.  We love it with crackers and cheddar cheese on top.  Leftovers are great for chili dogs or frito chili pies.  Mmmmm.  I always double this so we have easy leftovers for my family of 5.  Also freezes REALLY well!  Love to put half in the freezer and a simple thaw overnight in the fridge makes reheating taste 100% fresh.

text:
I have to say I am quite perplexed as to how this recipe received so many stars. I made the recipe exactly the way it said and even used the allrecipes chili seasoning from the site and it turned out SUPER SPICY and WAY TOO SALTY so it was inedible until i fixed it by boiling a chopped up potato in the chili. It helped a little but I still had to add additional sugar to counteract all the salt. My husband and I, who both like spicy food, were also overwhelmed by the heat in this dish even though I only used medium salsa. Next time I make this dish I guess I'll have to use mild salsa and I will definitely not put any red pepper or salt like was suggested in the chili seasoning mix. I can't really give it a good rating since i couldn't really taste it. Sorry.

text:
This is such an easy and delicious chili recipe!  I used ground turkey to make it a bit healthier, and you would have never known the difference.  It turned out a bit thicker than I like my chili, so I used a full 3 c. of tomato sauce and doubled the salsa.  It was still nice and thick, but didn't stick to my ribs!  I used Pace Picante Medium, but since I doubled it, this made it a little too spicy.  Next time, I'll use mild instead.  Thanks for a great recipe!

I love this recipe. I used it for the first time I made chili. I now use it as a base recipe, and just play around with it. I never use salsa though, just didn't prefer it. I add alot of chili powder, garlic, onion, etc. It's a very good, thick, hearty chili. We always top it with sour cream and cheddar, and eat it with crackers. text:
The best and easy , easy , easy !! I used abour 3 pounds of Ground beef because it was all frozen together. Drained and rinsed the beans and used a whole large jar of salsa ( because of the extra meat ). I also used the whole packet of seasoning mix- about 5 or so tbsp instead of 4. We like things a bit on the spicy side :). Simmered for one hour and served with icy cold sour cream , grated cheddar cheese ,diced avacado with a squeeze of lime and crispy nacho chips on the side. Tonight , chili dogs !!!! Thanks Debdoozie !

text:
Growing up my best friend's mother made the best chili. Whenever she made it he'd call me (and the 3rd in our trio) and we'd find an excuse to come over right before dinner. This is almost exactly her recipe. To make Mrs. Smith's chili follow this recipe, but use pinto beans in place of the light kidney beans. Also, use one whole red onion sauteed with some minced garlic, a 1&1/2 teaspoons of cumin, and black pepper to taste. YUM YUM YUM.

text:
I thought this was very good, my husband thought it was fantastic.  I did add 1/2 a green pepper and only used 2 Tbsp of Chili powder.  I used 2-19oz cans of kidney beans, but pureed one of them as my daughter really doesn't like beans so I find this is a good way to hide them. I let it simmer for 2 1/2 hours.  Just before serving I added 1 Tbsp white wine vinegar to enhance the flavor of the beef. Will definately make this again.

text:
Made the Deb's Chili for dinner this evening and my husband rated it 5 Stars!  he said he liked it as much as my favorite chili which he has loved since we got married. I made it exactly as the recipe calls for which is something I never do as I love to experiment but in this case I found the recipe so simple and straightforward that I had to see if it was good 'as is' and it was.  I used the middle of the road spiciness in the Pace Sauce and was happy with that.  If you are a "heat" lover this will be too mild for you but the best part is how easily it cam be made spicier in the same number of steps.  Enjoy!

text:
This recipe is almost identical to a recipe I use for making Chili and also Mexican Lasagna.  I use Ranch style beans (rinsed) for making Chili, as the  Ranch style beans are so much more flavorful.  For the Mexican Lasagna, omit the beans, and alternate layers of flour tortillas (cut in fourths), meat sauce, sour cream, and mixture of Colby and Monterrey Jack cheese.  Delicious!  Also, I control the heat by the salsa I use - mild, medium, hot, etc.

text:
This is very similar to a recipe we've used for years as a "throw-down" chili when we've wanted chili but didn't have the time to spend hours cooking down thebeans and so forth. Serve this with cornbread - forget the crackers - either sweet cornbread or jalapeno cornbread. The author uses Williams chili mix but I have also used Cin Chili and Chow Time Chili mixes. They both offer a spicier base. The Cin Chili is from a two-time winner at Terlingua. She's a really nice person, to boot.

I call it my "man-slayer chili" as several relationships have been launched by this concoction.  It's always a hit with men and women ;)

text:
Thank you for this recipe.  I've tried several recies and this is my favorite.  I've tried for a long time to make chili without the tangy sour tomato taste.  This recipe takes care of that.  I would have given 5 stars, but I made a few minor changes and I'm still not sure I like the full 2 lbs of meat in it.  It's a little too thick for my taste.  I used Pace Picante Med for the salsa, used kidney beans and black beans, and since I couldn't find William's mix, I used French's Chili-O and added a little sugar. I'm entering this in a church chili contest next weekend!

Update -- My chili was not the favorite.  Almost everyone at church preferred a thinner chili. However my minister would only eat mine and came back for 2nds. Actually, I came home with only enough for 1 more bowl, so it was good, just not the winner.  I think my part of the country is not used to chili being that thick.

I have been in search of the perfect chili recipe for years.  I have spent hours in the past browning pork and beef...dicing and sauteing fresh tomatoes, peppers, garlic and onions...measuring half a dozen spices... and allowing the chili to simmer for hours. None
country:
None
text:
Wow, I've finally found a chili recipe that tastes like actual chili! The great thing about this recipe is that it is simple, pretty quick to prepare (tho you have to wait a few hours for it to simmer), and modifiable. I read a lot of reviews where people changed ingredients and it tasted great! 
Here's what I did: As soon as the meat was browned/onions tender, I added all the spices to the meat and stirred it well (before the sauces). I added some Worschire sauce and one chopped fresh jalepio. I also didn't have any tomato sauce, but had pizza sauce in my cupboard and that worked just fine! I added all the liquids and a little bit of water because it was too thick, and let it simmer for over 2 hours. I tasted it part way and it was missing something so I added Johnny's Seasoning Salt and that was the trick.
It was soooooooooooooo good.
Thanks for giving me a great chili recipe that I can use over and over! :)

text:
Best chili ever. I made one batch "hot, no beans" and one batch "mild, with beans" to accommodate my extended family's tastes, and everyone raved about it. People had 2 or 3 helpings, and my husband and brother finished up the leftovers later that night! 

My only suggestion is to use fresh garlic instead of garlic powder.

text:
I just made this recipe two times in the last month. Once for my husband and me and then once for a potluck at work. It was a hit! I used the hot Pace salsa and I found that it made it moderately spicy. I think next time I will add some chopped jalapenos to make it even spicier. Also, I browned the meat/sauted the ingredients separately (I used onions, garlic and bell pepper) and then added the tomato sauce and salsa and simmered on low/medium heat for a while.

Let me add my voice to those who praise this recipe.  It is the easiest, best tasting chili out there. I've been making it for years now.  No other recipe compares. I make very few alterations to the basic recipe.  I usually use a fresh salsa, a can of pinto beans instead of one of the cans of kidney beans and a full packet of seasoning from the "Carrol Shelby's" Texas Chili kit.

text:
This chili is amazing!  Far better than the chili recipe I was using for years.  I always felt that the meat in my chili was slightly bland and boring, the taste lacked depth, and it was far too spicy.  Then I followed this recipe exactly, plus I added a can of black beans, a can of diced tomatoes, and 1/2 a tablespoon of cinnamon.  It tastes wonderful!  The addition of salsa is perfect!  It's the best chili I've had in a long time, and it's so easy to make.  This will undoubtedly be my chili recipe from now on - thanks Deb!!!

text:
I made a few additions. With the ground beef and onion, I sauted a couple cloves of fresh minced garlic. I added a little chopped bell pepper; red, yellow and orange. Used 14 oz of tomato sauce and added 14 oz of diced tomatoes. Omitted the salt and pepper as it's not needed with the use of the salsa and chili seasoning. Used the chili seasoning to taste. After the chili was cooked I put it in the crockpot on low until dinner time. It was fantastic!

Added extra 1 tbsp of cumin powder , a tsp of chili powder, and a dash of cayenne pepper.

text:
This was the perfect chili recipe for me.  It leaves lots of room to add your own favorite chili seasonings.  I did some slight changes - added tomato sauce and a can of diced tomatoes with mild chiles (to equal 2 1/2 cups), used 1 1/2 tbsp of chili powder instead of chili seasoning, added a little cumiin, and of course I seasoned my beef spanish style (adobo, sofrito).  In the end it wasn't too spicy for hubby, and I added my red hot sauce to make the perfect bowl of chili. Went great with the Absolute Mexican cornbread on this site.

text:
This chili was very good.  I made some small adjustments to the recipe based on what other reviewers recommended: I used one 15oz can of tomato sauce and one 19oz of diced tomatoes (Primo sundried tomatoes).  I also added some red pepper flakes.  To finish it off, I added a spoonful of sour cream, cheddar cheese, and green onions to each bowl.  My husband said it was the best chili he's ever tried and wanted the leftovers for lunch and for dinner today.

I followed the suggestion of Jenn_77 and used one 15oz can of tomato sauce with one 15oz can of diced tomatoes. userID:
5494517
Display Name:
brois
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
37
favoritesCount:
53
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I pair this with Sarahs Chili Seasoning Mix from this site and it is simply delicious! I alter the following for the seasoning mix: 3 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, 1/2 tsp dry mustard; omit the cinnamon and bay leaf; add 1 tsp ancho chili powder and 1/4 tsp dry unsweetened cocoa. Makes 11-12 Tbs, depending how generous you measure. I use half of this recipe per 2 lbs hamburger. Thats the spice mix; for this chili recipe, I omit the black pepper and garlic salt, use one can each of tomato sauce and Rotell tomatoes and green chilis, and half of the seasoning mix mentioned above. One of the easiest and best tasting chili recipes you will find!

5

text:
Ive made this for years now and it is delicious! Ive tweaked it to become my own and even won a contest with it!  Its terrific as is, but lends itself too many modifications to personalize your own award winning chili!
I use fresh mild salsa, ground turkey and add corn and black beans ( with the kidney beans) and my own sweet secret ingredient, half a cinnamon stick while it bubbles for a long time on the stove! It is sweet and just a tiny bit spicy and my family adjusts the heat with Chohula hot sauce. Its requested at every family gathering  and even on vacation in the summer! Enjoy the original and then make it yours. Thank you Deb Doozie for helping me make the best chili ever!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2020-01-26T21:24:01.83
helpfulCount:
0

text:
I generally cant stand when people review with tweaks, so let me first say this recipe is perfection when the directions are followed to a T. That said, I use chili beans in place of dark red kidney beans, half turkey/half beef, and add a 12oz bottle of IPA, 4 oz of coffee, and a packet of beef stock concentrate. Ive gotten in the habit of making this recipe at least twice a month because its so easy and it makes so much - easy to munch through the workweek when things get busy, unless its football season in which case were lucky to have enough for two bowls after using most of it to make nachos on Sunday!

Display Name:
angelinamarie3

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5239802.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe! And I admit, the salsa ingredient threw me- but I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome. Reviewing as written- it isnt perfect. This will make a VERY thick chili, as is. So, I ended up needing to add in another 1/2 cup of tomato sauce leftover from the large can, and then dumped in the remainder of the 8oz of salsa leftover from the 16oz minimum of the jar. When you let a dish simmer on low for 1 hour- liquid dissipates! When I checked the dish (as written) after 30 minutes- it was THICK & DRY! It was necessary to add the extra remaining liquids. 1/2 an onion also depends on the SIZE of onion. I ended up using an entire small (baseball size) onion & still felt I had to add a bit of onion powder to gain the proper ratio. 

As far as flavor goes- this is really good! One of the basic chili seasoning packets from McCormick is the equivalent of 4Tbsp. (I wish the recipe would have hinted towards or stated that!) But this is also one you may want to sit overnight & let the flavors seep. I found it to be much more delectable the 2nd day. Reheating is a breeze! And it goes perfect with cornbread. Definitely keeping thing one, but adding more tomato sauce, entire jar of salsa & some additional beans because the quantity of ground beef is a bit on the heavy side for only 2 cans of kidney beans. I also added a pinch of cumin & garlic, and topped with some shredded cheddar to serve. 

I cant say it it award winning in comparison to recipes that take a handf

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a huge hit for my family this evening!  I have six kids who can be pretty picky eaters and they all went back for seconds!  I had to make a few minor changes to the recipe so I wouldnt have to make a trip to the grocery store.  Instead of using ground beef I started with a frozen 2 1/2 lb beef roast with the whole jar of salsa (Herdez) in the crockpot, turned on high.  I cooked about 4-5 hours until roast was tender.  Took roast out, trimmed off fat, shredded beef into nice bite-size chunks and skimmed some fat off liquid in crockpot before adding shredded beef back to crockpot.  I then added the rest of ingredients minus one of the cans of tomato sauce I was short on.  I had to replace with about 3/4 cup of chicken stock to thin a little.  I cooked for another hour on high.  I served with shredded cheese, sour cream and deep-fried corn tortilla chips (from grocery store bakery).  Thank you for your recipe!  It was a big help as I was able to use groceries I already had on hand!

I was optimistic about this recipe due to the high ratings. If I could give this chili recipe more stars, I certainly would. I rarely use recipes, as I prefer to throw stuff together and create my own dishes, but I have to serve 30 to 40 men at my church tomorrow night. country:

text:
I liked the fact that this recipe called for tomato sauce and salsa. So I decided to use that and dress it up a bit more.  I made it with ground turkey meat and added minced garlic instead of garlic salt.  Since I am gluten free, I didn't use the chili seasoning mix.  Instead, I used chili powder, paprika, salt, pepper, oregano, sugar, basil and oregano.  I also ground up a red pepper and 2 jalapeo peppers to spice it up and a whole onion.  I sauted the ground up red peppers and jalepenos and 1/3 cup of the onion in butter for 4 min. until tender.  I used a can of green chilis and 1 can black beans and 1 can of kidney beans and cooked it for 20 min. to let the flavors blend.  I tested it on my grandkids and the pot was gone in 15 min.  They were coming back for more!!!!  They LOVED it!!!! I know I added a lot and it isn't the same recipe as above, but the chili seasoning mix has gluten and I like using my own spices anyways.  My grandkids raved and told me it was way better than my other recipe.  They liked that one okay, but I decided I wanted  to feed them something that they would really like.  So happy I found this one to use.  Thanks

This is now our base chili recipe. We change it up to suit our tastes---we like black beans, pinto beans and kidney beans in our chili, and also like to add a can or two of fire roasted tomatoes instead of plain tomato sauce or plain tomatoes. I love the idea of how adaptable this recipe is. If you have guests that can't handle heat, just use a mild salsa, or crank up the heat if it's just for us. Leftovers are delish next day also!!

This is my "go to" weeknight chili recipe. I seem to always have the ingredients on hand to make it work. text:
I loved this recipee. changes I made were: 1 1/2 lbs hamburger, 1/2 lb hot ground sausage, 2 15 oz cans tomato sauce, 1 can dark red kidney beans, 1 can spicey chili beans, hot red pepper, 1/2 tbs butchers blend black pepper, 1 clove garlic, medium salsa, and cayenne pepper (amount is personal preference). While brown the meat, I added all ingredients in a slow cooker. I added the meat when down browning and let it cook on low all day.

city:

country:
None
text:
Im rating this recipe as written. In my opinion, its a bit bland and just average. A lot of this recipe depends on prepackaged chili seasoning, which varies greatly from brand to brand. The author of this recipe admitted that the particular brand she used is difficult to find (and I could not find it) and resorted to McCormicks Mild Chili Seasoning. After simmering for 90 minutes, I was unimpressed. That is where the 3 stars come from. Its not horrible, but its not spectacular. It would work nicely in a pinch if your using it as a supplement to another dish, like chili dogs, taco salad, etc. It really doesnt work as a stand-alone dish.

I try to make recipes on this site the first time exactly as written. Used Pace Picante Mild as suggested. I couldnt find Williams Chili Seasoning so used McCormick. Half teaspoon of salt and half teaspoon of garlic powder. Three small cans of tomato sauce. Let it simmer for 2 hours and served over rice with sour cream, shredded cheese and Fritos as toppings. So easy and surprisingly good too! It was a little mild for my tastes but hubby thought it was perfect so I may use Pace medium next time.

text:
I adjusted the recipe to make 3lb.  Ground beef. 

I used the Chili Seasoning Mix by Terri on this site, to this I did add 2t of Chili powder.

Because it was was a little thinner than I like I  made a ruex w 2t of AP flour, stirred in and let it simmer 1.5 hours...it was thick and hardy,  its jusr RIDICULOUS ?? how good this chili is.  It's the best Chili I've ever made, actually the best I've had.

This chili was absolutely delicious, it was delicious fresh off the stove and it's even better today!

It is a phenomenal chili recipe that I will most certainly make many more times. 

THANK YOU FOR SHARING DEB!!!! 

IT REALLY IS SO SOOOO GOOD!

text:
Ive been making this chili recipe for many years and dont know why I havent reviewed it before now.  It really is a blue ribbon winner and a family favorite!  I always seem to have everything on hand and probably make it once a month or so because it is so easy to put together, nutritious, and delicious!  We buy grass fed ground beef on sale and keep it in the freezer, beans & tomato sauce from Costco.  I always use 4 different cans of beans (red kidney, white kidney, black, garbanzo or pinto) as theyre so nutritious and it stretches the chili for a few days and freezes well.  I also add some Trader Joes green salsa along with the red salsa to give it an extra zing but only use about 1/4 tsp. black pepper because  my husbands stomach is sensitive.  Shredded cheese finishes it off.  This is also a great vegan dish by omitting the meat and cheese.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-08-03T12:18:16.623
helpfulCount:

Definitely recommend this recipe to anyone who is currently searching for a nice chili recipe right now online!!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
TO DIE FOR!  Delish is the only words for this.  I made this using a crock pot to simmer for a tailgate party at work and used the Chili seasoning Mix II recipe.  I wanted to use New Mexico Chili powder, but could not find any, so I purchased the dried ones at the grocery store, toasted them for 5 minutes on 325 (until you start to smell them),let them cool and ground them up in a dedicated coffee grinder I use for spices.  Gave it just the right amount of kick.  Not overpowering at all.  I LOVED this!  It was a huge hit and got lots of compliments.  Make it and you will not be sorry!  **Warning** You may want to make two batches because one will be gobbled up faster than you realize!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was hesitant to try this recipe but couldnt find my normal go to recipe. Glad I did, not only is very tasty but easy to put together! I used mild pace picante sauce with 1 can of tomato sauce and 1 can diced tomatoes for texture (14.5 oz each). Also for added texture I used 1# ground sirloin and 1# cubed stew meat cut into small pieces. Along with the light and dark kidney beans I added a can of pinto beans with jalapeos.  For the chili seasoning I used 1 packet of McCormick, and fresh minced garlic in place of garlic salt.  I will definitely be making again but will try with medium pace picante sauce because I feel it can use alittle more heat! Thanks for sharing!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight, and it is REALLY good. The flavor will vary greatly depending on which chili seasoning mix you use, and the salsa will make it vary quite a bit. I used a mild, unchunky Texas home-made salsa, and the seasoning mix came from this recipe on Allrecipes.com: Chili Seasoning Mix II 

I found it slightly lacking in a bit of a bite, so I added about 1 tsp of chili powder and 1 heaping tablespoon of fresh minced garlic, also about 1 tsp of onion powder. It still has to simmer a bit longer, but I think this is the best chili I have ever made. A perfect medley of smokey sweet flavor. I wonder if a tiny bit of paprika could add to that flavor...Well, something to try for the next time. 

This is a great recipe, super simple, and tasty!

I made this recipe last night for a chili cook off tonight. I was knocked out over how easy it was to prepare but truthfully the flavor seemed a little off last night. I chilled it over night and this afternoon got it out and put in the crockpot to gently heat. I was so pleased when I tasted it after warming. The off flavor was gone, and the consistency was thick and perfect! I did add some extra chili powder for my own personal taste, but it was really good just as listed!

text:
I have made this recipe more than once and it is SOOOO BORING but it can be turned into something amazing!  Here is what I added to the recipe to bring out some bold flavor and to make it a 10+:  Add 1 can italian stewed tomoatoes (14 oz), 3/4 tsp dijon mustard, 2 cloves garlic, 2 green bell peppers diced, salt to taste, 2 tsp honey, two dashes of worstechire sauce.  If you add these ingredients before you simmr for an hour it will go from blah to fantastic!  My guests LOVE the better version and I had a house full of people who couldn't believe that I could turn the blah chili into something amazing.  Wish I had doubled the recipe!

text:
Delicious!  I have found my go to chili recipe!  I used 8 oz of salsa, a 15 oz can of tomato sauce and one can of mild Rotel.  I pureed all of that before adding the beef.  Next time, I'll cut the ground beef to 1 lb. and cut down a little on the black pepper.  I used mild chili seasoning and the flavor was great.  I threw it in the slow cooker on low for about 5 hours, and it was perfect at suppertime.

Display Name:
Nancy Feeney

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty and very easy! The salsa is key, so don't leave it out. Very easy to adjust recipe to accommodate individual needs. I was cooking for my parents who can't handle too much spice anymore (Dad's 78); so I made this chili with mild versions of the chili powder and salsa. My parents love chili but have been avoiding it for the past few years.

The recipe was still excellent, even with the mild chili powder and mild salsa.  If you (or someone you cook for) has a problem with spicy or hot dishes, I can recommend this chili. Just don't lessen the amount of chili powder too much,  I used the amount called for and it wasn't too spicy but enough to actually taste like chili. A dollop of sour cream is a tasty topper and helps mellow the spiciness further (Dad's chili). Serve with bread, as well, I find that helps soothe the stomach.  I grated some Monterey Jack to top Mom's chili (her stomach isn't quite as sensitive as Dad's). For myself, I topped my serving with Pepper Jack cheese to up the heat a bit.  
 I'm looking forward to making  this chili again (very soon!) when I'm cooking just for myself. I'm sure regular chili powder and hot salsa would be perfect for me. Chili freezes and reheats quite well, IMO. I'll  freeze it in individual servings and it will be perfect for lunch at work. A whole pot of chili just for me, LOL!

this was amazing! i didnt use the salsa brand which DEBZ recommended, just used the cheapest one i could find in the supermarket. But it still turned out great! 
NOTE to myself would be to eliminate garlic salt altogether and use real garlic (not garlic powder which also has some salt in it i think?) because the addition of all the canned beans and seasonings and salsa already has alot of sodium inside - i think my chilli became a bit too salty because of that!

This is excellent!!  After reading other reviewers' suggestions, I added some chopped green pepper and tomato, as well as some brown sugar.  I also added about a tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce (always a good idea with any beef-based soup or stew, in my opinion).  Finally, I did not have pre-made chili seasoning, so I made my own (see Chili Seasoning Mix II recipe).  Everybody loved it!  Will definitely make again.

text:
This is a keeper for a basic, easy to alter recipe.  I changed it up a little to suit my family's tastes.  I used a pound of ground beef and a pound of mild Italian sausage, threw in about 3T of crumbled bacon, and cooked it with the onions, minced garlic, and some hot chili powder since we like extra heat in our chili.  For the salsa, I used a jar of chipotle salsa, which gave it a nice smoky flavor, and I omitted the garlic salt since I used fresh garlic in the beginning.  The result was a nice, spicy chili that had a good depth of flavor.  It was great on a chilly night!

text:
Great chili recipe, which I've refined over the years to suit our tastes.  Instead of 2 lbs of ground beef, I split 1 lb of ground beef with 1 lb of Hot or Sweet Italian sausage.  Cook both in Liquid Smoke and Worcestershire.  Also we love beans so I add one extra can of dark kidney beans.  The tomato sauce is a very important flavor component, usually a good one with garlic in it does great.  We've tried the mushroom tomato sauce, it was definitely not for us.   A can of fire roasted tomatoes is also a great addition.  Thanks for posting this one so long ago, it's been a great staple in our meals!

My husband likes thick chili, but this stuff is super thick...like you could eat it with a fork thick. I  also throw in a dash of cayenne pepper since our chili mix (McCormick's) isn't super spicy...My husband LOVES this chili and so do I.  Perfect amount of heat!

text:
I did not win my company's chili cook-off but the recipe was easy and very tasty. We loved it. The hardest part was browning the ground beef and chopping the onion. 

I'm not sure how much 4 tbs of chili mix is but I used 2 packets of McCormick's Classic Chili seasoning.  Also, it did not say what kind of salsa to buy so I got the Southwest style. Further, I could not find 8 oz jars of salsa in my grocery store so I went with a 16 oz jar of salsa. Also, I used salt and fresh garlic instead of garlic salt.  Finally, I dumped it in a crock pot and let it cook for 3 hours the night before and then reheated in the crock pot when I got to work.

text:
Doubled the recipe. Used 4 lb ground beef. Browned in saut pan, drained, and then sauted onion & 2 tsp minced garlic in some of the drippings. Added some of the beef back to the pan & added 8 Tbsp (entire recipe) of "Chile Seasoning II" on this site as well as some of the tomatoes. Transferred this mixture to 2 slow cookers, added the rest of the ingredients. Substituted diced tomatoes plus some tomato pure  for the  tomato sauce. Also used 2 cans kidney beans plus one can pinto beans in each slow cooker.

Display Name:
Marie

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a chili girl.  I love it, deeply and profoundly.  I found this recipe while looking for a good chili recipe to make for my husband and I.  I needed to find a good one, because up until this point (marriage)  I had been having my Mom's homemade chili, but now it was officially time to grow up and make my own chili.  So I did, sort of, with this recipe.  I used a cross between Deb's recipe and my Mom's, and, I must say, that it makes a dang good chili that gets rave reviews.  Here is what I added: used a whole onion instead of half, a 15 oz can diced or crushed tomatoes, 3 cups of salsa instead of 1 cup, a can of chili beans with the juice instead of the can of light red kidney beans, and a green pepper when I have it.  Also, to make it easy, I just use a 15 oz can of tomato sauce, which is a little less than she calls for, but I make up for it in my other tomato ingredients.  I always serve it with jasmine rice, cheese, and onions.  Again, love this recipe!!!

text:
I've been making this recipe for two years now and I realized it was time for a current review. It is fantastic and versatile. Make it as is or use it as a base to suit your needs. I use it as a base for chili sauce for chili dogs and burgers (just use less liquid), as a straight up chili, or for turkey chili ( sub the beans for black beans, beef for turkey, and throw in a can of corn). This is my favorite recipe I've found on this site so far and will use it until my day's end. I've never had anyone not comeback for seconds. Thanks Deb!!

Display Name:
Valerie Cain Cuff

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/33699.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is very easy to make.  I love a bowl of thick, meaty chili and this was a great recipe for that.  However, I am very sensitive to spice.  Anything that has any "heat" at all in it is most always a turn off.  Unfortunately, the low sodium chili seasoning that I used had some heat and it didn't mention it on the label.  I just used the packet which wasn't quite 4 tablespoons, it was short by half a tablespoon.  With cheese and crackers added, I still managed to eat a bowl and the next time I think I may just stick with chili powder since I can't handle the heat of the chili seasoning.  I'm the only one at home that will eat chili, so leftovers are going to work with me.  I know there are people there who enjoy hot and spicey foods.  Thank you for sharing this simple recipe!
Review:
Rating:

text:
This chili was just what I was looking for. Keep in mind, chili is a HUGE category of food, and this recipe might not be right for everyone on every occasion. I'm from the north, but have lived in the south, including Texas, so I know a lot of people have firm ideas about what chili should be; how hot, how meaty, etc. This chili is great as a standard recipe, similar to Wendy's-style chili and something hearty and solid to feed a diverse group. I made it for a group of visiting Irishmen, and they enjoyed it over rice. That may freak out some purists, but that's how they eat chili. :o) I enjoyed the flavor, and was able to make it in a crock pot after just sauteing the meat and onion. Easy and crowd-pleasing! Thanks!

userID:
17386570
Display Name:
MovieFan

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this dish for a rainy weekend on 02/21/16.  First, I used a great quality 2 pound beef brisket in lieu of the ground beef. I grilled the brisket outside for about 10 minutes on each side to give it the proper color.  I brought it in and sliced it into bite sized edible pieces; it was rare in the center, so I knew it would be tender later.  It was placed into a crock pot.

Next, we followed the recipe, but added the following: 1 beef bouillon cube,  4 cloves of garlic, 2 Bayleaf's,  1 Tablespoon rock sugar.  We only used one can of beens and added  one-half cup of water.

After simmering an hour, it seemed heavy on the onion, but later, it dissipated.   We cooked it for 4 hours on high in the crock pot, stirring occasionally and sampling as we went.  We turned it off and let it stand overnight and the re-heated it for 1 hour before we ate it a lunch.  Topped lightly with shredded cheddar cheese.  DEE-LISH !!!  5-STARS!  Girlfriend says it's "restaurant quality!"  I say, BS, it's far better than any restaurant can make.  Try this dish, you will love it.
Review:

country:
None
text:
Thanks Deb, have been making this for years and let me tell you that this is the best Red Chili recipe ever. I have never rated any recipe before but am compelled to do so because of the wonderful flavors. I am also a chili fanatic growing up in Colorado where chili recipes of all sorts are king, red or green. I had to order the Williams Chili Powder as it is not available locally. I only add 2 more ingredients. I dice up Flank steak into 1/2 inch cubes then brown them and add to your recipe. I also add diced Lumbre green chilis for added heat and flavor which I order from Hatch New Mexico. Funny thing here is that of all the people I know that we share recipes with none of them will admit that this is the best they have ever had, yet their spouses will secretly tell me that this is much better. People out here are very proud of their own chili and would never confess that someone elses is better. Have taken it to work for potlucks and usually there are at least 2 other renditions and was told by almost everyone that this was the best. All except the other chili makers. Also, the addition of a good fresh grilled sweet corn is a plus served on the side which can be added if desired. We find that most will add it after testing a sample. Thanks again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a bunch of times and eventually started putting my own twist on it. I suggest chopping and de-seeding, 6 Jalapenos, 2-3 poblanos and toss those in. Then add between a 1/4 and half cup of honey. Finally, use serrano peppers to add heat. Of course you will want to leave the seeds in. My wife and I cut up two or three and that makes it pretty delicious. The good part about adding heat this way is you can buy like a half dozen serranos and just add more to get it to the potency you like. If you go too spicey, just increase the honey. it's win win.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
I don't like the Chili recipes with all kind of tomato products in them, tomato juice, tomato sauce, diced tomatoes.. It makes me feel I am eating tomato soup with some meat mixed in, and no doubt will result in some heartburn later ..
This recipe is all but that. It has a good ratio, meat to tomatoes , to beans. I made my own Chili seasoning mix. "Sarah's Chili Seasoning mix" from this site. Served with corn muffins.

text:
This has been my go to chili recipe for years! Quick, easy, and super good. Friends and family have request this recipe over and over. For awhile I made exactly according to recipe, but I have found it's super adaptable. I've used black beans, adjust seasoning to taste, and doubled batch easily. If you're looking for a great tasting incredibly easy chili, this is it! One last thing, this chili is great to freeze in small portions and take out later. Hope you enjoy!

text:
My husband made this for our church's chili cookoff and won! He added an extra pound of hamburger, substituted the fresh onion for the equivalent of dried minced onions and used 2 cans of original Rotel in place of the salsa. It was super simple too! He browned and drained the hamburger then chucked it and everything else in the slow cooker on high for 3 hours until it was hot! It was such a crowd favorite that by the time he was announced the winner, there was none left for those that wanted a taste (unless you licked the pan...which was tempting!)

I followed the recipe the first time I made this, and it was okay but lacking something.  The next time, I took my hubby's advice and added a can of diced tomatoes (I had basil, garlic, oregano seasoned ones on hand) along with my hubby's secret ingredient of 2-3 Tbs of honey.  The slightly sweet with the spice of the chili seasoning is the perfect blend of flavor.  Will probably continue to make this recipe w/ my modifications.

I'm sorry, but I made this and it finished in the middle of the pack in a Chile Cook-off at work, and the competition wasn't that tough.  While it wasn't bad, I found it to be somewhat bland.  I must admit, I like stronger spicing and more heat than most people, but a dozen people tasted it and judged it average.  Then again, I've done this Chile Cook-off three times and always finish in the middle of the pack, and I only made this recipe once, so maybe it's the cook.

None
text:
This recipe is great as-is. The first time I made this, I followed the recipe and used our Medium salsa, it was too spicy for my liking but my husband was happy with how spicy it was...next time i'll go with mild.
  The second time I made it: I didn't have enough chili powder so I substituted with chili-garlic powder, and cut out the garlic salt... my mistake, too much garlic.  I didn't add the salsa (because we didn't have any in the house).  Also I substituted the tomato sauce with pasta sauce because that's what we had in the house - my husband said the chili tasted like a meatlover's pizza.  Regardless of my mistakes, IF you follow the recipe as-is (like I did the first time), it's a great recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe packed amazing flavor for such simple ingredients. I did customize it for my personal taste. I added chopped green and red bell pepper along with some diced garlic, green chili peppers, and onion to my ground beef for some fresh flavor and color. I also seasoned my beef with some black pepper, season salt, and itialian seasoning. Reduced sauce to one can and added can of chili ready diced tomatoes. Used Mccormicks reduced sodium chili seasoning packet, the extra salt isn't needed if the meat is seasoned properly. I was sceptical of using salsa in chili but used Pace Picante mild and I'm glad I did. Added all ingredients to my crock pot and turned on high for about 1hr 30mins to 2 hrs. Served with cheddar cheese and crackers  used left overs for chili cheese dogs the next day :). This is my new go to chili recipe my son and fianc agree this is a winner.

Display Name:
chlorine Eileen

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Let me first begin this review by saying, yes this is the only chili recipe for you.
Cooking for me has developed since age 8-ish and to this day I pride myself on having a collection of only five star recipes. This chili recipe is no exception.
If you want to make this chili the very best here is what I do:
Add one can of drained yellow sweet corn
Substitute the two cans of kidney beans for one drained and rinsed can of black beans
Drizzle Kahla on top before cooking it makes all the difference in the world.
I would say about 2 to 3 tablespoons.
Make sure that you drain the ground beef completely  before you add the remaining ingredients, even if you have to use a strainer.
Garnish with avocado slices finely shredded Mexican cheese , fresh jalapeno slices , sour cream and a few crumbles of cornbread.
Serve with tortilla chips.
ENJOY!

text:
This recipe had really good ratings but didn't have enough veggies for my taste and I wanted some spice so I added the following which made it THE BEST CHILI I'VE EVER MADE!

Added:
-30 oz diced tomatoes
-1 chopped green pepper
-1 chopped red pepper
-1 chopped jalapeno pepper (seeded)
-1 chopped pablano pepper (seeded)
-3 tsp fresh chopped garlic
-1/4 tsp cumin
-1/2 tsp crushed red chili pepper
-1 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper
-2 tbsp chili powder
-1 tsp sea salt
-1/8 tsp of Italian Seasoning
-1/2 tsp garlic powder
-1/4 tsp onion salt
-1/4 tsp sesame seeds
-1 tsp basil

YUM!!!

Every time I make this recipe people rave. I make a big pot adding 2 big cans tomato sauce, 16 ounces salsa, 2 cans black beans, 2 cans chili beans, 2 cans light red kidney beans, 1 can dark red kidney beans, all untrained.  one whole chopped onion. It freezes very well.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok. When everyone says they used this recipe in a cook off and won, they aren't exaggerating. In a last minute decision to join the cook off, I found this recipe and decided to try it. I've never made chili before, it was simple enough and the best part was it didn't take much time to make. I did however add some minor personality touches. I found the recipe to be too thick (probably because I drained the beans), so i added two beef bouillon cubes and a cup of boiling water. I used fresh garlic, garlic powder and sea salt instead of garlic salt. I also added fresh peppers from my garden to give it that extra kick. Yum! It was a hit and yes, I won the chili cook off! - oh and one word of advise, the most important step is to let it simmer for at least an hour! I tasted it immediately and it tasted like tomato sauce. Against my will, I left it alone and let it just simmer. Then it started tasting like chili. I'm sure those more versed in chili making know this last word of advise. I added for my fellow rookies. Thanks Deb for sharing.

text:
I was looking for a quick chili recipe that didn't have to simmer all day, and came across this. I think the recipe largely depends on what kind of salsa you use. I used a high quality salsa that was balanced in flavor, and really liked it. I also used homemade chili seasoning instead of a packet. I omitted the garlic salt, since the chili seasoning was salty enough, and used 2 (15 oz) cans of tomato sauce. I also used only 1.3 lbs of ground beef. My whole family really enjoyed this recipe.

country:
None
text:
I found this recipe a few years ago and it's been a staple for our family ever since. Because I like my chili thick and chunky, I omit the 2 1/2 cups of tomato sauce and use two, 28 oz. cans of diced tomatoes (including juice). For a lower fat option, I will also use ground turkey instead of ground beef, however the flavor is better with ground beef (this is a personal preference as my family can't tell the difference). Toss the entire recipe in the crock pot and let it simmer on low all day. You won't be disappointed when you sit down to dig in. I've yet to have a complaint when I've served this dish.

text:
Awesome recipe!  Both my husband and I love a good chili and this one certainly fills the bill.  Of course, we always tweak to personal preferences...so, being the avid hunter, the freezer is always full of venison.  Substituted ground venison for burger, cut out the salt (let user determine personal taste), decreased tomato sauce to 8 oz and used a qt of home canned stewed tomatoes in place of salsa.  Also added green pepper and a clove of garlic.  The Chili Seasoning Mix II by sal was an excellent seasoning choice as well...please try that recipes (with modifications as well...LOL).  Wonderful blend of flavors!

text:
Have made this many times, always a hit with my family (and coworkers when I entered it-and won- a cookoff!) . Recipe is great as-is, I however do opt to add a drained can of diced tomatoes simply to make it heartier and to add another texture element. I use the Chili Seasoning Mix II recipe from this site for my seasoning (though on that recipe I cut back on the flour a bit and bump up the spices, it's a great seasoning recipe that is FAR better than packaged mixes and I highly recommend making your own mix over packaged, no matter what chili recipe you are making). Simple and great recipe!

I just served this tonight and even my picky 7 year old boy ate two servings.  I had to use a large can of whole tomatoes because I didn't have any tomato sauce.  I liquified them in the blender, measured out 2.5 cups... still delicious!  We ate this with rice and cheese... and what I really loved about it was that it was technically ready to eat right away.  I let it simmer for an hour as instructed, but that seems unnecessary from my experience.  I will definitely use this recipe all the time!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of my husband and I's all-time favorite recipes, but I've gradually made some changes in the 2-ish years that we've been making it.  Firstly, I use a full 29 oz. can of tomato sauce (3 5/8 cups rather than 2 1/2 cups).  I have experimented with using hot salsa and it turned out wonderfully and I'd highly recommend making it hot, but my favorite salsa I've used so far is the Guy Fieri Original Salsa... it gives a very hearty, savory flavor.  I also add chopped green bell peppers immediately before serving.  They taste great with the chili and gives it some crispiness.

None
country:
None
text:
I doubled the recipe to 16 servings, served 7 people just enough leftovers to maybe feed 3.  It's delicious!!!  I would recommend just making a lot more because everyone seems to eat so much of it.  I feel so proud that I made it.  I did change it up just a little after reading other suggestions.  Instead of only using tomato sauce, I used some chopped/stewed tomatoes because I wanted some texture and I used more chopped onion than they said.   I also used fresh garlic and added 1/2 the amount of salt.  I added about 1/3 cup of beer (keep in mind I had a double recipe) and about a tablespoon or two of brown sugar. Topped it with medium chedder, but I actually think it was better without the distraction of cheese on top.  Served with cornbread with butter and honey.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A wonderful base recipe but here are my own modifications. I like to dice up and add a variety of fresh peppers (jalapeno, poblano, etc.). I also prefer to add a 15oz can of corn (no salt added), substitute 1 can of black beans for the kidney beans, and reduce the salsa to just 4oz. For the seasoning, I use the Chili Seasoning Mix II recipe (but reduce serving to 1/4 cup) and omit the pepper and garlic salt from the original recipe. Be sure to shred cheese from a fresh block rather than buying the bagged Kraft stuff - which is terribly dry. Serve with Homesteader Cornbread - incredibly moist and delicious!

text:
I have made this chili several times and enjoy it for many reasons. This is a simple recipe and it has great flavor. I made a few changes due to personal preference. I took the beef down to 1 1/2 pounds. I also use pinto beans instead of light red kidney beans. Last, the chili is a bit thick for my taste so I add a 12 ounce beer prior to simmering. Served with a little cheese on top and a side of jalapeno. Great recipe, thanks for sharing!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This was a great base recipe to work with. I never made Chili before, and I loved the simplicity of ingredients used. The only changes that I made were to use an entire onion, instead of 1/2 onion. So I wouldn't have any waste, I used one 15 oz can of tomato sauce and one 16 oz jar of salsa...it's not the exact measurements the recipe used, but I figured salsa has a little bit more flavor due the different seasonings and peppers used than tomato sauce and it was great. I used one 1.25 oz packet of chili seasonings which is approx 4 tablespoons.  I seasoned my meat and onions with a little seasoning salt and garlic salt...careful to not over season...drained my beef..and mixed everything in the crockpot and set it on low for 8 hrs.

I like that the recipe had so few ingredients, however I felt the proportions were off. For me this is WAY too heavy on the meat and light on the beans. I'll probably make it again and double the amount of beans. Additionally, I found a recipe for my own chili seasoning instead of using the packaged chili seasoning. I recommend making this substitution. You likely have all of the spices in your cabinet and you can avoid the MSG and other chemicals in the packaged seasoning.

text:
My husband was very skeptical (and not a fan) of chili when I said it was for supper.  This recipe has sold us both!  This is my first time making chili and it was so good!  I didn't have any chili mix on hand, so I used the Chili Seasoning II recipe from this website instead.  Substitutions I made were: 1 can of black beans and 1 can of dk. red kidney beans; 1 can tomato sauce, 1 can Rotel diced tomatoes with green chilies.  (Ended up with LOTS of heat to this chili)  Browned frozen meat on stovetop and tossed in crockpot to let it simmer for a couple of hours.  Served with some french bread.  Perfect for those cool winter evenings!

My family always raved about my chili but for something different I tried this recipe. The ooo's and ahhh's on every bite were crazy. My husband asked if I could make it exactly like this again!

I will be making it again next week, exactly the same :)

I get a lot of compliments on my chili and it makes me feel like chili is "my thing."  Thanks to this great recipe!  Now I do tweak it a bit just by adding additional beans ( I add about 4-5 cans.) I do like to add black beans, pinto, red, and kidney beans.  I also use more salsa than it calls for because I like my chili to go a long way.  I don't use chili seasoning mix anymore but instead just dash chili powder and cumin to taste.  Mmmm!

This really is a winning recipe.  I made a few small variations such as garlic cloves vs. garlic salt, and introduced 1/2 teaspoon of sea salt instead.  I also added Black bean salsa and a small can of mexican salsa.  I also introduced diced tomatoes into the recipe.  In a nutshell, I was forced to do this years chili contest for my department, so I went into this with reluctance but found that it was a big hit. In fact I won both of best Chili award and the People's Choice award.  I was elated!  So, this receipe will gets 5 stars.

userID:
3270496
Display Name:
Marisa R.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
101

340

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/440454.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, So I did a few things differently but it turned out great anyway.
First, I had 4 different homegrown chiles that needed using because they were getting soft and shriveled. So I added them in with the onion and burger. I also added a big pinch of minced garlic during that step.
I used 2 (15 oz.) cans of tomato sauce because my guestimation was off which lef
t me with 3 cups of tomato sauce rather than 2 1/2. I also did a booboo with the salsa, I had a 28 oz. jar of medium heat, Pace Picante Sauce and I was telling myself "eh, I'll eyeball that 8 oz. (1 cup)" Um... yeah, ended up with about 2/3 of the jar in there. So to compensate, I measured the seasoning as directed but added the entire packet of (low sodium) chili seasoning.
As it simmered, I have to admit it started smelling like boiled Pace Picante.... TOTALLY my fault, not the recipes. So I started brain storming on what I could do to off set that a little. I ended up adding 2 heaping tablespoons of brown sugar, a pinch of salt and a few dashes of cayenne pepper. Totally did the trick and the family loved it. Turned out slightly sweet with a nice underlying heat. Served with a little reduced fat cheddar, light sour cream, fresh onion and cilantro as toppings. Super Easy and a must make again recipe!  Oh! And since it was really saucy (because of my messed up measuring) I added a can of pinto beans and a can of black beans to the mix.  Still was very tasty and we got plenty for leftovers or perhaps the freezer.

country:

text:
This is a very good starter recipe! I had all day to play in the kitchen so I just made a few improvements & changes from stuff I had on hand..after the ground meat onion cooked & drained mix I added a can of Ranch Style beans instead of the ones here,then in addition to the garlic salt I added 2 chopped cloves of fresh garlic,1 tblsp chopped jalepenos,1/2 can corn,2 tblsp green pepper,1/2 jar of Texas-Texas hot sauce,1 tblsp Herdez salsa verde,2 tblsp canned mushrooms,1 pint of chopped tomatoes canned,1/2 cup of prepared pico de gallo(had made already in fridge..for this you could just add some chopped fresh cilantro). Then I put it all in a big crockpot & cooked all day. I made some Mexican cornbread to go with it and served over Fritos corn chips and cheddar/Monterey Jack Cheese on top. It is HEAVENLY!(especially for a Texan like me!)Thanks Deb for the inspiration & ideas!

I made this chili recipe today & it was amazing. I did make a few changes. I used ground turkey instead of ground beef & since I didn't have garlic salt I used minced garlic instead. I added it to the meat along with the onion. I also add some of the chili seasoning to the meat while it was browning. Then I put everything in the slow-cooker to let it simmer all day. When it was done I topped it with some shredded cheese & had some fresh cornbread on the side. I will definitely be using this recipe for now on.

text:
This recipe has all the stuff that I use but I added 1&1/2 tbl. spoons of white sugar, 1 15oz can of sweet corn drained, 2 small cans of tomato paste, 3 stalks of celery cut up, 1 or 2 green bell pepper cut up, 3tbl. spoons corn starch as a thickener.This is more than campfire chile, and you will know what I mean when you dig in. P.S. don't forget the cornbread. If you want 5 stars add these items to the sauce and simmer for 1 hour. If it starts getting to thick just add small amounts of water.

I'm not a chili fan, but my husband is and he gives this recipe 5 stars! I did make the following changes: used 1 1/2 pound lean ground beef, used 1 clove minced garlic instead of garlic salt, added 1/2 each of diced red and green peppers and only used 1 can light kidney beans. Watched it closely and found it didn't require 1 hour cooking time. We topped ours with shredded cheddar, a dollop of sour cream and a sprinkling of crushed Fritos.

Delicious chili!  I did change a few things to go with what I had - cut it in half as well.  Instead of garlic salt added a finely chopped garlic clove, and instead of adding 1/2 and 1/2 for beans, I just used a can of light red. text:
Ive tried many chili recipes..many on here, many from friends. This is by far the best chili Ive ever had. It really does resemble Wendys Chili. I had no chili seasoning mix so I made my own using the chili seasoning recipe on here. Instead of tomato sauce, I used a can of stewed tomatoes. I added a can of mushrooms, chopped bell peppers for colour, chopped celery and 3 cloves of garlic. I also simmered the whole thing for 1.5 hours. Absolutely delicious!!

text:
Five stars for how easy this is!  It's a very good basic chili.  I thought it might taste too much like tomato sauce since it calls for 2 1/2 cups, but that was not the case.  I made it as is and really liked it.  You can adjust the spice, heat, sweetness, etc. based on your preference (and based on what type of chili seasoning and salsa you use).  I used Herdez mild salsa and McCormick Chili seasoning.

text:
AWESOME RECIPE. As a newlywed currently living with my in-laws, I find it difficult to cook for 6+ people (the bro-in-law brings friends over frequently), three of whom have to follow special low-starch diets, and still have downtime, and this recipe is perfect! I adjusted for 8 servings, used a half-pound more beef than the recipe called for, added an extra couple cans of beans, and used a whole 16oz jar of Mrs. Renfro's Roasted Salsa. My husband and new family loved it, the mother-in-law could actually eat it, and there was enough to pack for the husband's lunch for days afterwards. Grade-A recipe!

Display Name:
Erin K.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/133898.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was a little hesitant to use jarred salsa but I really think it's what elevated this chili from good to great. I added some veggies at the beginning (bell peppers and onions) and stirred in bittersweet chocolate and minced garlic about thirty minutes before I served it. I also left the lid off the slow cooker for the last hour to let it really thicken up. Mine was almost too spicy (I used Hot Salsa and made my own chili seasoning from a recipe on this site: Chili Seasoning Mix II. I should have tested the ancho & chipotle powders I was using because they were super spicy. I tempered the heat with a few scoops of peanut butter...doesn't change the flavor a bit and actually gave the chili a nicer body) Best chili I've ever made.

userID:
2574830
Display Name:
liznatl
isPro:

3

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/151949.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This reciepe looks similiar to mines that I submitted.. Just a few varitions.
NO METHOD, NO MEASURING ONLY YOUR TASTE BUDS ARE NEEDED!

CUT UP:
Celery stalks
Onions
Green and Red Bell Peppers
Bay Leaves (I crushed them up)

Throw it in with your meat so it can all cook together.

Brown meat 
1 package of Tennessee Pride Sausage  HOT
1 package of Italian Sausage
Top Round/ Top Sirloin (use a steak thats tender) Cut in small/bite size pieces

Season your meat mixture to taste with:  
Sea Salt
Black Pepper
Onion Powder
Garlic Powder
Cumin
Chili Powder
Mined Garlic
Oregano

Once your meat has browned,  drain it and add

Tomato Paste (garlic flavor but can use plain)
Diced Tomatoes with green chilies in Chili Sauce (not sure of the brand got it @ Wal-Mart )
1 jar (16 ounces) salsa (Medium)
Stewed Tomatoes
1 small can of green Chilies
 Rotel diced tomatoes and chilies
Dark Kidney Beans

Add couple cans of water and let simmer

Taste best when refrigerated overnight.

text:
UPDATE: MADE THIS AGAIN BUT THIS TIME I FOLLOWED DEB'S INSTRUCTIONS TO THE LETTER. THE KEY IS TO USE A GOOD QUALITY CHILI SEASONING. I ADDED AN ENTIRE BOX OF CARROLL SHELBY'S SEASONING (ALL BUT THE SALT PACKET - EVEN THE MASA / THICKENER). I ALSO USED 80/20 BEEF AND DRAINED MOST OF THE FAT (BUT NOT ALL OF IT). MY "BEANS IN CHILI" HATING HUSBAND EVEN LIKED THIS... WOW! :) Not bad, although not my "favorite" chili recipe (by far). This just wasn't spicy enough for me. Actually, this didn't really taste like chili at all (but the texture was spo on...). I made this last night in my slow cooker. Set on low for 8 hours and then put it all in the fridge this morning so that when my dad comes over, he will have something hearty to eat (he's working on a bathroom remodel project). I followed Deb's recipe *mostly* to a T except for how I cooked this and subbing a 14.5 oz. can of diced tomatoes & green chilies (undrained) / a 15 oz. can tomato sauce for the 2 1/2 cups of tomato sauce called for (per another reviewer's suggestion). I also added an entire 16 oz. jar of medium-heat Pace picante sauce and a whole packet (~ 6 T worth) of chili seasoning. Topped with shredded cheese and crushed Frito's, this was pretty good. Thanks for sharing! :-)

text:
I didn't think that I would find a chili recipe that I liked as much as my mother's, but this is delicious!  

I "mostly" followed the recipe, but made the following changes: 1/2 t. garlic salt and also 1/2 t. of Petey's Garlic & Onion seasoning; 1 full packet of chili seasoning (it needs it - otherwise starts to lose flavoring); about 10-12 oz. Med. chunky salsa (I used a generic brand to keep cost down and still was yummy); 1 can pinto beans in addition to kidney beans.

The first time I made this I used morning star veggie crumbles in place of hamburger. I used chili mix II, but it was too spicy for me. Lastnight I made this recipe again and it was a HUGE hit, with vegans, veg heads and carnavoirs alike!!! I used a whole onion,veggie crumbles, subbed half mexican tomatoes for the sauce, added 5 heaping T. of chili seasoning pluse a 1/2t of cumin.I used the Chili Seasing MixII from this site, but I cut the cayenne in half because it's just too spicy for me.

text:
I loved how simple this recipe was to make.   The first time I made it I followed it exactly and it was very good.  The second time I did make a few changes however due to what I had available and preference. My husband liked it better with these few tweaks...
I chopped some green bell pepper and added crushed garlic while I was browning the onion and beef.  I also added a small  can (I think 8oz) of garbonzo beans and a   15 oz can of black beans that have been rinsed and drained instead of 2 kinds of kidney beans.  My husband came home and was like "what smells wonderful?  I want some of whatever you're cooking!"  My kids even thought it was yummy with crackers and cheese melted on top!  This is a recipe I don't think you can mess up and cooks in about an hour but can be simmered longer for even better flavor.  thanks Deb for the easy chilli!

text:
The best part of this website is finding great recipes then making them your own!  I liked this chili very much and over the years have tweaked it so it better suits my families taste.  I use 1 lb ground turkey, 1/2 onion, 1 tsp crushed garlic from a jar, 2 T mild chili seasoning packet, 1 can of diced tomatoes, 1 can of tomato sauce, 1/4 C Pace mild salsa, 1 can dark red kidney beans, 1 can white beans (great northern).  I serve it over saffron rice with a little sour cream and some corn bread.  Thanks Deb!

text:
Good, easy recipe. I used "Hot Chili" seasoning, medium salsa, 1/2 can dark kidney beans, 1/2 can of black beans. I slowcooked on low for 3.5 hours and served for dinner the next day (reheated in slow cooker). It was very tasty. Garnished with cheese and sourcream and cornbread on the side. Boyfriend and I both thought it was delicious, especially compared to ease of prep. Will possibly use more tomato sauce, and probably add some chili powder for more seasoning. Will also use hot salsa instead of medium, as it wasn't very "alarming" at all.

This is my new chili recipe.  I made a few minor changes.  I didn't use a can of light beans, just 2 cans of dark.  I didn't use an onion just alot of onion powder. Incredibly easy, and even more delicious! I typically use 1# ground beef and 1# ground turkey, and 1/2 tomato sauce and 1/2 crushed tomatoes.
